chamber.xscript.para: Wednesday, 10 April 1963 1 Mr. SPEAKER (Hon. Sir John McLeay) took the chair at 2.30 p.m., and read prayers.
ROYAL VISIT FILMS.

Mr. STEWART.- I address a question without notice to the Minister for the Interior. Was an official film taken of the very impressive parade of the Queen's Colours at Manuka Oval during the visit of Her Majesty? If so, will the Minister consider making available to motion picture theatres and television stations suitable extracts from the film for use during the playing of the National Anthem so that Her Majesty may be depicted reviewing our own Australian troops?

Mr. FREETH.-The honorable member has made an excellent suggestion. There was a fairly complete film coverage of all functions during the royal visit. I do not know exactly what film was taken on the occasion referred to by the honorable member, but I shall certainly look into the matter to see whether his suggestion may be adopted.
TERM LENDING FUND.

Mr. HOWSON.- My question, which I address to the Treasurer, relates to the term lending fund which was created last year, partly from funds held by the Reserve Bank of Australia as part of the statutory reserve deposits of the trading banks. Has this fund achieved the objects for which it was created? Has it in particular helped to provide long-term export credit, and has the Treasurer now received a request from the banks concerned with the fund to enlarge it? If so, will the Treasurer consider enlarging the fund?

Mr. HAROLDHOLT.- I think it is fair to say that the fund has been achieving the purposes that we had in mind for it when it was established. The fund was designed to enable the banks to provide longer term credit for various development purposes, including the financing of export credits and the provision of assistance to industries and rural producers. My understanding of the position is that calls on the fund have proved to be of such dimension that, taking commitments into account, the fund as originally constituted may not prove adequate for any considerable time ahead. Consequently, talks are now in progress between the Governor of the Reserve Bank and representatives of the trading banks with a view to ensuring that adequate funds will be available. When I am in a position to state more precisely the outcome of those talks I will be glad to do so.
AUSTRALIAN COUNTRY PARTY.

Mr. CALWELL.- I direct a question to the Postmaster-General and acting leader of the Australian Country Party. Does the view expressed by the Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the Country Party at the annual conference of the Victorian Country Party on 2nd April last that Australia was selling her national heritage bit by bit every year to foreign investors represent the official attitude of the Australian Country Party? In the honorable gentleman's view, does the opinion expressed by the Deputy Prime Minister conflict with the official policy of the coalition Government on this matter?

Mr. DAVIDSON.- The reply to the last portion of the honorable gentleman's question is, " No ". It is well known that the Minister for Trade has done a mighty job in expanding the scope of Australia's trade and development and in the preservation of Australian industries. Anything that he has said recently must be considered in that context. I am sure that all my colleagues agree with me when I say that on his present visit overseas he will continue to act to Australia's advantage.
POSTAL DEPARTMENT.

Mr. FOX.- I preface my question to the Postmaster-General by saying that many public telephone booths are not as clean as they could be. Of course this is not the fault of the Postmaster-General's Department but rather is the fault of the public which uses the booths. In the interests of public health, will the Minister arrange for the regular disinfecting and cleaning of public telephone booths?

Mr. DAVIDSON.- The condition in which telephone booths are sometimes left by certain vandals gives rise to quite a problem, which my department tries to handle. I shall see whether anything further can be done in the matter of inspecting booths from time to time. Perhaps the honorable member can advise me of telephone booths in certain areas which require particular attention. We are doing our best to solve this problem. I only wish that some people felt a greater need to preserve decency.
SALES TAX.

Mr. BEATON.- I preface my question, which is addressed to the Treasurer, by referring to the Treasury practice of imposing sales tax not only on the cost of a completed article but also, in the case of country areas, on the freight charges incurred in transporting that article to the country. Is the Treasurer aware that because the major proportion of consumer goods purchased in country areas comes from the capital cities this practice adds to costs in country communities? In effect, the further one lives from the capital cities the higher is the sales tax. Is the Treasurer aware also that goods manufactured by decentralized country industries, which are struggling to compete with city organizations, are loaded with this additional and unnecessary sales tax disability? In view of the fact that the Government admits that there is a special unemployment problem in country areas, will the Treasurer examine the present practice with a view to removing this discriminatory taxation burden on country people and country industries?

Mr. HAROLDHOLT. - I can assure the honorable member that this matter has been very carefully and very sympathetically examined on many occasions. The practice which now obtains - I remind the honorable gentleman that it obtained also when Labour was last in office - has been found to be the only workable one to adopt. I repeat that it has been given full consideration, but when it has been considered no one has been able to suggest a better practice.
ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE.

Mr. HOLTEN.-My question to the Minister for Air relates to the recent crash of a Sabre jet aircraft in the Lake George area, which was caused by engine failure and resulted in the pilot, Group Captain Mather, having to use the ejection apparatus to bail out. Has the actual cause of this engine failure yet been ascertained?

Mr. FAIRBAIRN.- A court of inquiry has been set up to investigate this accident, but I have been informed by the Air Member for Technical Services that it was almost certainly caused by the failure of a fuel pump. However, Avon engines have two fuel pumps and there must have been some malfunction of the second pump, otherwise the engine would have continued to operate successfully. Since the Royal Australian Air Force fitted modifications to these engines two and a half years ago this is the first occasion on which engine failure in the air has caused a pilot to eject, and, therefore, be unable to return to and land his aircraft safely at the nearest base. I think this record of performance shows the remarkable efficiency of Avon engines.
HOUSING.

Mr. GRIFFITHS.- I direct a question to the Minister for the Interior. Has he received correspondence from me twice in the last six or seven weeks, protesting against increased rentals being charged tenants of Commonwealth cottages at Belmont North in my electorate? Will he say why I have not received either a reply or an acknowledgement before now? Are increased rentals being charged in face of his department's refusal to service the area and is he using, as an excuse for the increases, higher costs of such items as maintenance, rates, and the like? Is it not a fact that his department does not pay municipal rates or carry out maintenance work in the village? Is it true that the tenants do their own maintenance and otherwise effect repairs and install essential services in the cottages? If this is so, will he take action to restore the status quo in rentals, pending a thorough investigation of the conditions existing in the cottages at the village to which I have referred?

Mr. FREETH.-I have received letters from the honorable member, but I was not aware that they had not been answered. I am sorry. I will have a look at the matter and see whether he can be given an answer straight away. I ask him to place the rest of his question, which was rather long, on the notice-paper.
WATERFRONT EMPLOYMENT.

Mr. WHITTORN.-My question is addressed to the Treasurer. As he was asked yesterday to allocate £500,000 of Australian money to assist in the relief of the volcano-stricken Indonesians, I now ask him how he would ensure that the Waterside Workers Federation would handle the goods purchased with this £500,000. I ask him, particularly, when the consignment of dried milk and bulk cooking utensils which was urgently requested by the Indonesian Red Cross, and which has been sitting on the wharf at Walsh Bay since last Friday, will be handled by wharf labourers and whether this instance of man's inhumanity to man is to be allowed to continue.

Mr. HAROLDHOLT.- I am sure all the members of the House have been watching with concern developments on the waterfront, which appear to indicate a revival of irresponsibility and leadership of a kind damaging to Australia's export trade and external relations. I join with the honorable member in expressing regret that a gesture of goodwill and practical help of the kind he has illustrated for us here is being frustrated by the failure of the waterfront union to load this cargo. I understand that matters relating to this course of conduct will be debated by the House later in the afternoon and perhaps that occasion will provide a better opportunity for canvassing these matters in more detail.
DEFENCE.

Mr. JAMES.- My question is directed to the Treasurer. Does he consider that the governments of countries in South-East Asia and Indian Ocean areas would be concerned about the establishment in Western Australia, by agreement between Australia and the United States of America, of a control centre for 20 or 30 mobile nuclear missile bases, which would be moving about among them? Has his Government made any attempt to ascertain the views of the governments of these countries, or has it ignored them? If any attempt has been made to ascertain their views, will he inform the House of the results? If the views of these governments have not been obtained, will be take steps to obtain them so that this House can be informed before it has to consider the bill authorizing the establishment of the missile bases control centre?

Mr. HAROLDHOLT-As the Prime Minister has already advised the House, legislation will be brought down and an opportunity provided for debate on matters of the kind to which the honorable gentleman has referred. If there is any information which I can secure for him which would assist him in discussing the particular matter he has raised, I will see whether it can be made available.
Mr. James.- We are asking for that.
Mr. HAROLDHOLT. - I shall see whether it is available.
SOCIAL SERVICES.

Mr. COCKLE.- My question is directed to the Minister for Social Services. Has the attention of the Minister been drawn to an announcement made by a Labour sen; tor of an alleged change of policy with regard to the payment of social service benefits to eligible persons who are discharged from mental hospitals? Is the Minister in a position to confirm the announcement, which has been given wide publicity by newspapers and radio stations alike? Under what authority can a Labour senator make an announcement with regard to a change of Government policy since announcements of this kind are usually made by the appropriate Minister?

Mr. ROBERTON.-My attention has been drawn to this unauthorized announcement, allegedly made by an Opposition senator. I am indebted to the honorable member for Warringah for raising the question in this House. Announcements of the kind are to be deplored. There has been no change of policy with regard to pensioners who are admitted to mental hospitals, except insofar as the honorable senator may have been referring to events before the general election of 1949. Since that time the Social Services Act has been interpreted to give the greatest possible advantage to pensioners in those most unfortunate circumstances. I would remind honorable members that the

Social Services Act provides, and always has provided, for the suspension of benefits when pensioners are admitted to mental hospitals. But the act also provides for the restoration of payments as soon as pensioners are discharged from mental hospitals. Such payments are made retrospective, covering a four-week period. That policy has been faithfully followed for fourteen years, and it will continue to be followed. If the policy is changed, then the Minister for Social Services, no matter who he might be, will make the necessary announcement in the traditional way.
AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL FLAG.

Mr. MONAGHAN.-My question is directed to the Leader of the House. In "Hansard" of 26th March, 1963, the Prime Minister is reported to have informed the House of an extension of the scheme whereunder Australian national flags are issued to schools in Australia. The scheme was extended to include boy scouts and girl guides. I now ask whether the Government will consider a further extension of this commendable scheme to cover all schools in the Australian Territories, including mission schools of all denominations.
Mr. HAROLDHOLT. - I shall be happy to convey that commendable suggestion to the Prime Minister.
BROADCASTING.

Mr. NIXON.- I address my question to the Treasurer. Because of the national importance of and Australia-wide interest in the Commonwealth Budget, will the Treasurer endeavour to make arrangements with the Postmaster-General to have the Budget speech broadcast by all Australian Broadcasting Commission stations covering rural areas, so that country people may enjoy the benefit of hearing the Budget proposals for the ensuing year?

Mr. HAROLDHOLT. - I shall be glad to discuss this suggestion with my colleague, the Postmaster-General. I can only hope that the message conveyed by the Budget will make palatable hearing for the listeners.
ANZAC DAY.
Mr. REYNOLDS.- I preface my question, which is addressed to the Treasurer, by mentioning that recently I put on notice a question addressed to the Prime Minister in these terms -
As 25th April, 1965, will bo the fiftieth anniversary of the events at Anzac, will the Government give special consideration to the striking of a special medal to commemorate the occasion?
The Prime Minister, in a brief answer which I received yesterday, stated -

This matter has been considered recently by the Government, but it is felt that the issue of a medal to commemorate the 50th anniversary of Anzac Day would not be of a significance commensurate with the relatively large expenditure that would be involved. Consideration is, however, being given to some fitting way of celebrating this very special anniversary.

I now ask the Treasurer: Does the Government not recognize that its penny-pinching attitude in this matter violates the sentiments of all ex-service organizations and is shockingly out of touch with the Australian public's sacred regard for this most important event in Australia's history? What estimate of costs did the Government have before it when it made the decision? Has the Government any precise notion of what alternative means it has in mind for celebrating the occasion? Will the Government give an undertaking that it will review this decision and strike the necessary medal?

Mr. HAROLDHOLT. - In the first place, I repudiate any suggestion that this Government lacks appreciation of the significance of Anzac Day. In fact, the Prime Minister, the Government and, indeed, our supporters have always been scrupulous in their own observance of Anzac Day and have shown a proper national recognition of its importance to this country. I am not able to name all the considerations which influenced the Prime Minister when he took the decision which was conveyed to the honorable gentleman. I can do no more at this stage than see that what has now been said comes to the right honorable gentleman's notice. I am quite certain that he would not have replied as he did without weighing the answer quite carefully against other possibilities which may have come to his mind.
PHARMACEUTICAL BENEFITS.

Mr. BUCHANAN.-My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. It is understood that the Minister for Health recently arranged a meeting between leaders of the friendly societies and the Federated Pharmaceutical Service Guild of Australia in an attempt to resolve their differences over the application of the 5s. charge required for every prescription under the national health scheme. Can the Minister inform the House of the result of the talks and whether, as a consequence, there are proposed amendments of the act that will ensure equality of trading practices in dispensary shops and chemists' shops?

Mr. SWARTZ.- It is a fact that my colleague, the Minister for Health, arranged a meeting between representatives of the Federated Pharmaceutical Service Guild of Australia and the friendly societies to discuss this subject. My understanding is that the meeting did not resolve the problems which were being discussed. The report by the independent chairman of the conference is still being studied by the Minister, and I shall advise the honorable member as soon as possible what the result of that study is.
ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE.

Mr. ARMITAGE.- I wish to ask the Minister for Air a question. Have there been recent discussions between the British Aircraft Corporation and Royal Australian Air Force officers or the Minister concerning the replacement of the obsolete Canberra bomber? Has the Government made any decision to purchase the TSR-2 bomber when it becomes available? Does the Minister, keeping in mind the fact that, even if orders were placed now, it could be some years before the new aircraft would be delivered, consider that a decision on replacement of the Canberra bomber is urgent?

Mr. FAIRBAIRN.- I have had discussions with Geoffrey Quill, who is the sales representative of the British Aircraft Corporation and who has been in Australia on a couple of occasions recently trying to interest the Commonwealth Government in the TSR-2 bomber. These discussions showed that this aircraft, when produced, should be outstanding, but my personal feeling is that the date by which it will be produced is so late that the Commonwealth Government would be unable to accept this aircraft. We could accept it only if we were to hire or borrow other aircraft to use in the meantime. I agree with the honorable member that the Canberra is an old type and is becoming obsolete. For that reason the Government is looking at means of replacing it. The Government has decided that the Chief of the Air Staff, Sir Valston Hancock, should accept an invitation from the French Government to go abroad early in June and be present at the International Air Show at Paris. He will have an opportunity, while there, to inspect all the aircraft that would be available if and when the Government should decide to replace the Canberra.
HOUSING FINANCE.

Mr. CLEAVER.-My question is addressed to the Treasurer. I refer to the right honorable gentleman's recent confirmation that Australian banks are now releasing substantially increased amounts for housing loans. As building societies have helped to establish a splendid partnership between banks and governments, through the Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement, I ask the Treasurer whether steps may be taken to urge the banks to increase also their advances to such societies.

Mr. HAROLDHOLT.- The House is well aware of the interest this Government has always shown in the co-operative building society movement, and the practical assistance given by my colleague, the Minister for National Development, when he negotiated the Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement and secured the agreement of the States to the allocation to cooperative building societies of 30 per cent, of the funds available under the agreement. Recently, while addressing publicly a gathering of representatives of the cooperative building societies, I did urge that banks and other financial institutions should ensure that co-operative building societies shared in the increased funds that they were making available for housing. I think the suggestion was quite well received. I have seen indications that the co-operative building societies have received some increased provision, although I do not say it has been enough for their requirements. I hope that this expression of the Government's view will not be without influence on the assistance given by banks and financial institutions in this direction.
ARMY TRAINING.

Mr. FULTON.- My question is addressed to the Minister for the Army. As the increased defence vote may favour the Army - or even if it does not - will the Minister consider establishing a permanent camp in the tropical area of Australia, so that troops may familiarize themselves not only with the area itself but also with conditions there? Such a step would also provide an excellent opportunity for medical staff and communications staff to become familiar with the hazards of the terrain in which they would probably have to operate if we were called on to defend this country.

Mr. CRAMER.- The honorable member may know that we take every opportunity to give troops exercises in areas in which they will encounter tropical conditions. As a matter of fact, great numbers of such exercises have been carried out in the north of Queensland.
Mr. Fulton.- But not far enough north. That was at Mackay. They should be in the tropics.
Mr. CRAMER.-Well, I am afraid I did not catch your exact words. I cannot hear what you are saying now because of all the rumbling coming from your colleagues.
Mr. Fulton.- I meant in the tropics, where the troops were called on to assemble and train before going overseas in the last war.
Mr. CRAMER.-Well, I will have a look at " Hansard " later and see what you did say, and give you a proper answer.
TELEVISION.

Mr. LESLIE.- I have a question which I want to address to the Postmaster-General. I ask him whether the fact that no applications were received for the proposed commercial television transmitting station in the Northam-York district, to serve the central agricultural areas of Western Australia, will have any effect on the Government's intention to provide a national television transmitting station in this area. Will the invitation of applications for a commercial station to serve this area remain open?

Mr. DAVIDSON.- I can assure the honorable member for Moore that the fact that no applications were received for a commercial television licence in the areas to which he referred will not in any way affect the announced intention to establish a national service there. The honorable member also asked whether the invitation to submit applications for a commercial licence in the areas will remain open. If we are advised, or if he can advise me or the board, that some interest there now wishes to submit an application, I shall see that such application is processed.
INCOME TAX LEGISLATION.

Mr. O'CONNOR.- I ask the Treasurer whether it is a fact that a committee on taxation, presided over by Mr. Justice Ligertwood, presented its report to the Government more than eighteen months ago. What are the reasons for the Government's failure to say what it proposes to do about implementing the recommendations of the committee? If the Government intends to implement the recommendations, can the Treasurer say when the Government will do so?

Mr. HAROLDHOLT.- I have answered questions on this topic on a number of occasions since the report was received. On each occasion I have referred to the complexity and variety of matters covered by the report of the Ligertwood committee. In effect, it roamed over the whole field of our income tax legislation. Any one who has been following the attempts in the United States of America to implement tax reform there will have some conception of the kind of problems we face here. I may say, Sir, that the report of the Commissioner of Taxation on the report of the committee was larger in size than the report of the committee itself. It was also a document of considerable complexity and, of course much importance.

Work on this matter has been proceeding in the Department of the Treasury and in the office of the Commissioner of Taxation. In order that concentrated attention could be given to the problems and to the preparation of the necessary legislation, I asked Mr. Denis O'sullivan, who recently retired from the position of Commissioner of

Taxation, whether he would be willing to accept an appointment to the Commonwealth Treasury as a consultant and to devote his time and effort to the preparation of policy recommendations and the drafting of legislation that may be necessary after further Cabinet discussions. He has now been engaged and is working in the Treasury on this very matter.

I am not able to say at this point when legislation will come forward to the House. It may be that we can deal with most of the matters together, but I think it more likely that we will have to deal with them in parts. However, I give the House my assurance that we want to produce the best result we can from the study that is being given to these problems and that any delay will not be the result of lack of attention either by the Department of the Treasury or by the special consultant we have now engaged.
ANSETT TRANSPORT INDUSTRIES LIMITED.

Mr. MACKINNON.-My question is addressed to the Treasurer. What steps can the right honorable gentleman take to undo the almost irreparable damage inflicted yesterday on Ansett Transport Industries Limited by the Leader of the Opposition? I ask him to investigate the possibility of taking some action that will protect the integrity of such large organizations from this type of irresponsible and undermining attack, which must destroy public confidence and damage the interests of many shareholders - and I might add that I am not one of them.

Mr. HAROLDHOLT.- Whilst I may deplore, with other honorable gentlemen, the attack made by the Leader of the Opposition, I do not altogether share the view of the honorable member for Corangamite that the Leader of the Opposition has worked irreparable damage Ansett Transport Industries Limited, because I think the people of Australia are sufficiently levelheaded to form their own judgment on an issue of this kind. I feel that Mr. Ansett himself made a dignified reply to these charges. He invited the Leader of the Opposition to repeat them outside the sanctuary of privilege. I am quite certain that the great majority of Australians, who have watched with admiration the courage and ability shown by this Australian in building up a great commercial airline, will form their own assessment. They will not be regardless of the fact that the recommendation on which the Government acted was the unanimous recommendation of the body specially appointed to make recommendations. In giving effect to that recommendation, of course, the Government has been guided by the informed view of those people who are able to assess the relative merits and capacities of the contending candidates.
EDUCATION.

Mr. BRYANT.- Did the Treasurer receive last week-end a newspaper distributed by the Students Representative Council of the University of Melbourne, highlighting the needs of education in Australia and stressing points that have been made from this side of the House on numerous occasions? As the newspaper was obviously expressing the view of many people who are closely involved in education, will he reconsider the Government's refusal to appoint a national committee of inquiry into the needs of Australian education generally?

Mr. HAROLDHOLT.- The honorable gentleman is well aware that very full statements on the Commonwealth provision for education have been made in this House by the Prime Minister and others speaking for the Government. He should be aware that the amount provided directly and indirectly by this Government for education far exceeds anything provided by any previous government, and certainly any previous government which would have enjoyed the support of the honorable gentleman. We have to contend with a great many claims in the field of development, defence and social services - just to name a few - as well as education. Having regard to the many other important claims upon the revenues of the Commonwealth, I do not think any one could fairly a. due that we have not adopted a liberal attitude in the provision of funds for the Sta: governments and also in the special field of tertiary education, in which our provision has far exceeded that contemplated by any earlier government.
DEFENCE.

Mr. FORBES.- My question, which is directed to the Minister for the Army, is supplementary to the question asked by the honorable member for Leichhardt. Is it not a fact that no area in Australia, tropical or otherwise, provides climatic conditions equivalent to those of South-East Asia? Also, is it not a fact that this is one of the things that make the stationing of a battalion group in Malaya - which honorable gentlemen opposite are pledged to withdraw, if they can - so valuable to this country?

Mr. CRAMER.- Every word that the honorable member for Barker said is definitely true. I should like to add - the honorable member knows it - that at Canungra we have one of the finest jungle training centres in the world. It really prepares troops for the conditions that they have to encounter when they are sent to countries beyond the shores of Australia. So most of our troops are actually trained under jungle conditions. Of course, they do not get at Canungra the atmosphere that they get in Malaya, which was referred to by the honorable member.
BAUXITE.

Mr. NELSON.-I address a question to the Minister for Territories. Has the period allowed the British Aluminium Company Limited to formulate a programme for its Gove bauxite deposits run out? Has the Minister informed the company that he will review its lease only if it undertakes to produce alumina nearby, as has been arranged by the Pechiney company for the bauxite from its surrounding leases?

Mr. HASLUCK.- The exact position is that British Aluminium Company Limited, in respect of the single lease that it holds at Gove, had until 31st December last to submit a proposal. It submitted a proposal by 31st December. As a result of subsequent discussions with the Government the company was asked to submit an amended proposal before the end of February and it did so. That amended proposal is now under examination.
TAXATION BRANCH OFFICES.

Mr. ANTHONY.-I ask the Treasurer whether he will give consideration to a proposal that may help to decentralize the Taxation Branch. At present the main offices of the branch are in the capital cities. The Postmaster-General's Department and the Department of Social Services have regional offices in country areas. Those local offices give country people more personal and intimate service. I am sure that if the Taxation Branch established regional offices and did likewise the result would be more accurate returns and speedier lodging of returns. This would help not only the Government but also taxpayers.
Mr. HAROLDHOLT.- I shall be glad to examine the practicability of the honorable member's suggestion.
UNEMPLOYMENT.

Mr. LUCHETTI.-In the absence of the Prime Minister I direct a question to the Treasurer. Is the right honorable gentleman aware of the serious continuing problem of unemployment throughout Australia and particularly its severity in certain areas where the position is chronic? Does the right honorable gentleman recall a promise made by the Government to provide full employment for the mine workers of Australia? Does he know that 9,000 mine workers have lost their jobs since that promise was made? In view of the present situation in mining areas I ask the Treasurer to consider favorably the action taken by the United Kingdom Chancellor of the Exchequer and to provide assistance for the establishment of permanent industries in depressed areas throughout Australia.

Mr. HAROLDHOLT.- The full answer to the matters raised by the honorable gentleman would take longer than I think the House would permit or desire at this stage. I would point out to the honorable gentleman that he creates a quite misleading impression publicly in the reference that he makes to the unemployment situation in Australia. What he might more usefully refer to is the special problem that exists in some centres. As my colleague, the Minister for Labour and National Service, has pointed out in detail, there has been a general improvement in the demand for labour, and in some categories of employment scarcities of labour have already been revealed. In some directions many of the young people who have just left school are being steadily placed in jobs. Recently my colleague's department has been receiving notifications of vacancies at the rate of about 14,000 a week and has been placing people in employment at the rate of about 11,000 a week. I am assured by the Minister that this rate of demand for labour is continuing. But that does not mean that there are not in existence particular pockets of unemployment. The honorable member will know that the Government has in various ways tried to give practical help to overcome this problem. It has provided additional approval for loan raising by local government authorities. It has provided special grants to the States for employment-giving purposes. The States have been given absolute discretion to spend those grants in areas where difficulties exist, and they do so in collaboration with the Department of Labour and National Service. The action taken by the Chancellor of the Exchequer which formed part of the recent United Kingdom budget decisions is worthy of examination, and I shall be glad to study it.
SPECIAL ADJOURNMENT.
Motion (by Mr. Harold Holt) agreed to -
That the House, at its rising, adjourn until Wednesday next, at 2.30 p.m.
WATERSIDE STRIKE ACTION.

Mr. SPEAKER (Hon. Sir John McLeay). -Ihave received a letter from the honor able member for Bruce (Mr. Snedden) proposing that a definite matter of urgent public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely -

The action of the Waterside Workers Federation and in particular the Melbourne and Sydney branches in engineering strikes deliberately designed to disrupt Australian sea transport and consequently to disorganize Australian national and international trade.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places. (More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places) -

Mr.SNEDDEN (Bruce) [3.17].- Mr. Speaker, approximately 22,000 waterside workers are employed in Australia. The great majority of Australian ports carry on in a reasonable fashion but at all times on the waterfront there is the likelihood of stoppages, strikes and general turbulence. Generally speaking, work in the ports of Australia, with the exception of Sydney and Melbourne, has been carried on, since the last legislation brought down by this Government, in a reasonable way. But a very dreadful situation has arisen in Sydney and Melbourne, where the Communistcontrolled executives in those waterfront ports are able at will to call a strike on or off. They can engineer strikes at the drop of a hat. As soon as they, in a dictatorial fashion, make a decision that there will be a strike, everybody has to walk off.

The consequences of a strike are very disastrous to the Australian nation as a whole and particularly to the men engaged in the strike. The trade of the nation is disrupted and there is a likelihood that trade in perishable goods will be destroyed completely. Strikes add to the cost structure throughout the Commonwealth. They bring general disruption. These results to the nation are insufferable. The men on strike suffer very severely from loss of wages and loss of future attendance money. The general secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation, Mr. Fitzgibbon, has, I believe, been trying his hardest to bring a state of peace to the waterfront. Unfortunately it must be admitted that Mr. Fitzgibbon is the captive of the Communistcontrolled executives of Melbourne and Sydney and is completely incapable of exercising any true power as the general secretary of the federation.

The build-up of stoppages that we have seen recently conforms to a specific planned objective. After legislation to amend the Stevedoring Industry Act was passed we had in Australia a period of peace on the waterfront which was unparallelled in our previous history. Indeed, the report of the Australian Stevedoring Industry Authority of that year pointed out that for the first four months of the financial year 1961-62 the loss of man-hours was so small that we were heading for an all-time record low and that the annual loss would be less than the usual average monthly loss. After Mr. Healy died and Mr. Fitzgibbon became the general secretary, the Communists managed to find time to rearrange themselves and to replan their programme. Having replanned their programme, they said: "This is not good enough. There are not enough stoppages. The loss of man-hours is not great enough. We shall have to assert our superiority over this man Fitzgibbon." Both the Sydney and Melbourne executives decided that they would take the right to declare stoppages out of the hands of the federal executive and assume it themselves. Without doubt, the purpose of this was to disrupt Australia's economy in accordance with the plans and the principles to which they adhere. They want to inconvenience the Australian people and, where possible, to harm them.

Then you ask the question, " Who wants the strikes? " The inevitable answer is, " The Communist leaders of the Sydney and Melbourne executives of the Waterside Workers Federation want the strikes". The reasons given for these stoppages are incredible. The executives say, "The reason for this stoppage is the question of annual leave" or "The reason for this stoppage is the question of margins ". In fact, at the time of those stoppages the case before the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in relation to annual leave and margins had been concluded and a decision was imminent. At a time when members of the metal trades unions and other unionists had presented their case before the commission, the Waterside Workers Federation was calling a strike about the subjects of the application. The conclusion to be drawn is that the federation does not care a jot about other unions. It does not care how they manage. If the circumstances occur, it is prepared to embarrass other unions as much as it can because this is all a part of the Communist planned build-up to assume control of all unions in Australia. What a futile, stupid reason to give for a strike when the full bench of the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission was considering the same subjects!

Another reason which the federation has given for stoppages is the monopolies of the shipping companies. What an incredible reason to give for a strike! In the first place, it is not a reason for a strike, and secondly, there are no monopolies. Another fascinating reason the federation has given is that its members are not receiving their share of Australia's productivity. It has used the word " productivity ". I see the honorable member for Blaxland (Mr. E. James Harrison) in the House. I am sure that at least he will give the word " productivity " the meaning that it should be given. Productivity is not an easy thing to define or to measure but the Communistcontrolled Waterside Workers Federation claims that productivity is arrived at by dividing the number of men working at a particular time into the output. The federation then claims a share of the result. In reality it wants not merely a share of the " productivity " but all of it. That is how the Communists operate, and that is one reason that they have given for a waterfront stoppage.

Then there are all kinds of local issues, such as the provision of protective clothing and higher pay for working in dirty conditions, which are given as reasons for stoppages. But such issues can be determined immediately on the spot by a board of reference. There is no need for a strike, as is demonstrated by the number of times on which a board of reference has determined matters with great facility.

Let me tell the House of a fascinating occurrence in Melbourne. A stop-work meeting was held at the boxing stadium. The reason given for the stoppage was to hold a meeting to support Fidel Castro. The whole Australian economy was held up while Melbourne waterside workers went to the stadium to hold a meeting to declare their support for Fidel Castro! Another interesting stoppage occurred in Sydney on 8th March. All men working on the Sydney waterfront walked off at 2 p.m. As they were walking off a public servant employed by the Australian Stevedoring Industry Authority asked the waterside workers the reason for the strike and they replied: " We do not know. We are just told that we are on strike." Off they went and not one stroke of work was done all that afternoon. At 5 o'clock the authority still did not know the reason for the strike. Then at 8 o'clock that night the mystery was solved when the State executive of the Waterside Workers Federation issued a press statement and gave "hostages" as the reason for the strike.

Perhaps not all honorable members know what hostages are. This nice colourful word was dreamed up by the Communist executive because it has appeal. The executive said to the men, "You cannot allow men to be held as hostages " and the men asked, " What does the word mean? ", as honorable members may ask what it means. When a man is suspended from work he is suspended for a working day, but if the port goes on strike the day following the suspension that day is not regarded as a working day for the purposes of the suspension. That is how the " Com." executive used the word " hostages ".

The executive claims that the Government should be kinder than it is to the waterside workers. What more kindness can you do than to provide, as the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. McMahon) provided, a right of appeal in cases pf suspension? Not only did the Government provide a right of appeal, but it also provided for the payment of compensation in the event of the appeal being upheld.
Mr. Jones.- But the judges are all oneeyed, as you are.

Mr. SNEDDEN.-All honorable members may not have heard that comment. In the characteristic, lofty objectivity for which he is so well known the honorable member for Newcastle has accused the judges of Australia of being biased.
Mr. SPEAKER.-Order! Did the honorable member for Newcastle make that remark about the judges?
Mr. Jones.- Yes.
Mr. SPEAKER.-The honorable member will withdraw it.
Mr. Jones.- I withdraw it.

Mr. SNEDDEN.-One might ask, "Is there rank and file support for the Communistcontrolled executive?" Very clearly the answer is that it has no rank and file support. When given the opportunity the rank and file tipped out the Communist candidate when a successor to the late Jim Healy was to be elected and elected the non-Communist Fitzgibbon. The rank and file does not want the Corns but it is power less at present to do anything about getting rid of them. For instance, Roach is acting general secretary of the federation because Fitzgibbon is overseas. Let me tell you how the Corns operate. They said to Fitzgibbon: "You are getting in our hair a bit. Off you go overseas and leave control of Sydney and Melbourne to us ". So now Roach is the acting general secretary. Recently he went all the way from Sydney to Melbourne to call a meeting but he could not raise a quorum on the Melbourne waterfront. If any one can claim that that indicates anything but a complete absence of confidence by the rank and file in its controllers I should be very surprised.

Let me deal now with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The A.C.T.U. is sick and tired of the Waterside Workers Federation but, while it is sick of it, it is stuck with it and does not know what to do. It has called the federation into conference on several occasions and has extracted the promise that the federation will act reasonably, in accordance with union principles. Having given the promise the federation representatives have left the conference without having the slightest intention of honouring it and immediately have called on other strikes. This leads to a very important question. The rank-and-file members are not behind the Communist-controlled executive, but how can they get rid of it? They have been trying, but cannot get rid of it. The only means by which they can rid themselves of the Corns is the secret ballot. This is the very thing that members of the Opposition have opposed violently and constantly. While I have been a member of this House all spokesmen on industrial matters on the other side of the chamber have said - it was said by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Calwell) in his policy speech at the last election - that the Labour Party stands for the abolition of the secret ballot in union elections. Honorable members opposite must know that when they stand against the secret ballot they are standing for the Corns, and until they get that clearly in their minds how can anybody have any confidence in the Opposition? On the industrial scene the thing which is most dearly held by the union member now is his right to the secret ballot, if he can fill the preliminary condition regarding the number requiring it.

We come then to the aspect of penalties. The Opposition has constantly said that it does not agree with the penalties contained in the legislation. How can honorable members opposite justify that stand in any way at all, when the whole of the Australian economy - the passage of goods, trade in general, and commerce and intercourse between the great Australian States - is being held to ransom and is having the brake put on it or is hobbled by the Waterside Workers Federation? Yet the Opposition says it is against secret ballots and the penalties contained in the legislation. How can it possibly hold to that view?

If the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Whitlam), the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) and the honorable member for Blaxland speak during the debate, I hope the Australian people will hear at least one of them say, " As far as I am concerned the penalties will stay ". I hope, more important even than that, that one of them will say, " I stand four-square behind secret ballots in trade unions ". Let us hear from one of them. Let us hear one of them say that. Or is the reality of the situation that the 36 faceless men whom we have heard about have to be consulted before the Opposition would say it is against secret ballots? Of course, if the question gets to the interstate conference of the Australian Labour Party, you can rest assured of the decision which the 36 men will take. They will take a decision against secret ballots, because many of them are Communists themselves.

Mr. WARD(East Sydney) [3.33].- Mr. Speaker, the raising of this matter by the honorable member for Bruce (Mr. Snedden) will at least serve one useful purpose, that is, the people of Australia - probably for the first time in this recent dispute - will hear the case for the waterside workers. The honorable member for Bruce is a lawyer. Outside this chamber he appears as junior counsel for the shipowners. In Parliament he continues the same activities on behalf of the same interests. I do not know whether he received a very poor brief, whether he spoke in complete ignorance of the situation, or whether his- purpose was to attempt deliberately to deceive the Australian public in regard to the exact situation which exists. He talked in generalities, but did not get down to specific disputes to show what is causing unrest on the Australian waterfront to-day.

It has often been said that the waterfront industry is a turbulent industry. Of course it is! It has been turbulent for very many years, but the turbulence has been due to the attitude adopted by the employers in the industry - the shipowners - rather than the attitude of the men engaged in the industry. Let me, in my limited time, deal with one or two specific instances to show the provocation to which the waterside workers have been subjected. The member for Bruce talks about the word " hostage " being a Com. word. That is always the defence employed by members opposite. But I think that when I explain what is happening on the waterfront to-day any reasonable person could put no other interpretation on the matter than to say that " hostage " is the correct word to use.

In July, 1962, a vessel called the " Riederstem " arrived in Australia. It was a cargo vessel carrying oil in tanks. The waterside workers claimed that the work of pumping the oil into wagons on the shore was their work, but this- was denied by the shipowners. Previously the oil had been brought in in 44-gallon drums, the handling of which had been the work of the waterside workers. The men were given a suspended sentence and, strangely enough, their claim was subsequently conceded, although they were penalized at the time they made their stand. It was eventually admitted that the claim of the men engaged in this dispute was correct, but they were given this suspended sentence and before it had been served the wool dispute occurred.

A Japanese vessel arrived in Australia to receive a cargo of Australian wool and one of the men engaged on loading it was injured. Immediately the men, on the grounds that their safety was involved, made a request to the shipowners that three men instead of two be employed on the wool stack. This request was rejected by the shipowners and the dispute then went to a board of reference, to which the member for Bruce referred. He said that on these matters there is no need for the men to strike and that disputes should be taken to a board of reference to be determined. This matter went to a board of reference and I will tell you, Sir, what happened when it dealt with the matter, it decided in favour of the shipowners and the dispute then went to an arbitrator. Do you know who he wa9? He was the chairman of the board of reference which had already rejected the men's request. So there you had as arbitrator the man who had already passed judgment on the men. He obviously upheld his own decision as chairman of the board of reference and rejected the men's claim.

The men were suspended for what were termed two normal working days. That was the penalty imposed on them. But the shipowners called in fresh men and asked them to continue this work and in no time there were 571 men involved. After they had gone on strike - this was the only way in which they could get the matter dealt with effectively - Mr. Justice Ashburner ruled that where bales were stacked four or more high four men were to be employed on the stacks. The shipowners had had two men on the stacks and the men asked for three. After the men had gone on strike, which was the only way they could have the matter settled, Judge Ashburner decided that four men should be employed on the stacks. So if there had been no strike on that occasion there would have been no justice for the men employed. But although the men were subsequently found to be correct in their claim, savage penalties had already been imposed upon the union and upon the members of the Waterside Workers Federation, who lost great sums of money through loss of attendance money and loss of pay.

Let me come now to a more recent dispute - the "Lake Eyre" dispute. In this instance the men were engaged in discharging bags of clay. They made a request for industrial clothing - to which the honorable member for Bruce referred - and when it was refused they took the matter to a board of reference. Their request for industrial clothing was rejected. The matter went to an arbitrator. He had been the chairman of the board of reference and upheld his own decision. But strangely enough, when a replacement gang was provided for the vessel the men's demand was conceded and they were given industrial footwear, aprons, washing time, and 6d. per hour penalty rate. If the men were right finally, in regard to the terms they wanted to apply to this work, the stoppage should never have occurred. Their claims were obviously just in the first instance. These are the things which are occurring and causing unrest.

In this case the authority determined that as the men had lost one day's pay and part of a day's pay, that plus two day's suspension was an adequate penalty, but before they had opportunity of serving this sentence another dispute occurred. This was not related to the first dispute and occurred on the "Port Aylmer ". It involved only six men and had to do with the placing of the men in the discharging of a railway truck. Because agreement could not be reached a dispute occurred. Then, because these six men employed on a different vessel were involved in a dispute the penalty imposed on the " Lake Eyre " men, being a continuing penalty, could not be satisfied until there had been a normal working day. They are the only days that count in cancelling out a period of suspension. The honorable member for Bruce was completely in error in describing this position. He said that if the port stops the next day, that day is not counted as a normal day. In fact, if one waterside worker is involved in a dispute it is not regarded as a normal day and does not count for the purposes of cancelling out a suspension. So if the men are suspended for one or two days and during that time a handful of men are on strike and remain on strike the men suspended remain suspended although otherwise their period of suspension would have expired.

I think you will agree that no body of men could stand for that state of affairs continuing in their industry. I commend the action of the waterside workers in standing up for their workmates and saying that this form of injustice shall not be allowed to continue.

This trouble can be dated back to 1956, when Mr. Justice Ashburner gave the employers the all-clear in regard to sling loads. Prior to that, in the various ports, according to the circumstances and conditions of employment, the waterside workers determined the sling loads, but from 1956 onwards the shipowners were allowed to load the slings as they wished. The judge had been of the opinion that the shipowners could be depended upon to deal reasonably with the men, but they almost immediately increased the sling loads and reduced the number of men working below in a vessel. The honorable member for Bruce tried to dismiss lightly the enormous additional profits that are going to the shipowners to-day. He treated them as being of no consequence. I believe that honorable members opposite are trying to use this issue to influence the electors at an important State election in Queensland and an important federal by-election In South Australia. That is the purpose behind the raising of this matter. If the Australian public listened to the honorable member for Bruce, they would believe that there was chaos on the Australian waterfront and that trade was being permanently affected. I challenge the honorable gentleman to dispute the figures I shall give now. In the year 1962, 3,333,000 tons of additional cargo was handled. In that same year there was a reduction of 3,750,000 in the man-hours employed in loading and discharging cargo. Taking a ten-year period, there was an increase of 7,250,000 tons in the cargo handled, with a reduction of 10,333,000 in the man-hours employed in the handling of that cargo. One would have imagined that the honorable member for Bruce would have suggested a reduction in freight rates for the Australian producer as being fully justified. If he is worried about what is happening to our external trade, why does not he criticize the overseas shipping monopolies that not only are exploiting the waterside workers but also are exploiting the primary producers of this country? [Extension of time granted.] In 1962, 1,016 fewer men were employed in the industry and 2.8 hours fewer per man per week were worked by waterside workers. The total average working hours per week for the waterside worker last year was 25.7.

Attendance money, which is now paid to waterside workers, was not introduced for the purpose of giving an additional reward to these workers for their labour, but was designed as a weapon. It was thought that a threat that attendance money would be withheld would coerce the waterside workers into working harder, under conditions that normally they would not have accepted. But this threat is no longer a deterrent against stoppages of work. The waterside workers have, in my opinion, acted properly as an organized trade union movement in calling stoppages where justified. There is now such an accumulation of debits in regard to attendance money that the threat of withholding it is no longer a deterrent. Many of the older men in the industry, who are now retiring, realize that they would have to be available for work for another ten years before they could hope to work off the debits that they have accumulated.

Let me deal with another dispute of recent times, the " Pateena " dispute. That dispute occurred, not because it was engineered by the Communist Party, as the honorable member for Bruce suggests, but because the shipowners decided that in loading the "Pateena" they would have two slings on the one hook instead of one sling. The waterside workers decided, for safety reasons, that they would not work with two slings on the one hook, and the men were then given a suspended sentence. Honorable members opposite try to make out that the present disputes are deliberately designed as a serious blow aimed by the waterside workers at our primary producers. That is utter rubbish. Is it not ridiculous that men who are not involved directly in particular disputes are suspended? The shipowners do not attempt to isolate a dispute. They allow it to extend to other men not directly involved, which results in additional waterside workers being suspended. Large numbers of waterside workers have not been allowed to work on the waterfronts at Sydney and Melbourne, while cargoes are held up for want of labour. While the " Pateena " dispute was continuing, the " Elmore ", loaded with potatoes, was berthed at No. 37 Darling Harbour wharf. This vessel was held up because of a shortage of labour to handle its cargo. If the shipowners claimed that they were worried about the primary producers, I would point out that the suspended waterside workers from the *' Pateena " dispute could have been allowed to unload the potatoes from the " Elmore ", where no dispute existed. It is quite obvious that the shipowners have embarked on a campaign of systematic provocation of the men.

Let us take the question of extra waterside labour under the roster system. The men have insisted that any extra men engaged shall be taken off the roster in their turn and allocated to hatches as labour is required, and that the foremen should not be given the right to select men, as they and the shipowners desire. In order to prevent preference being given to any employees on the waterfront, it was decided by the men that the right of the foremen to select labour should be taken away and the men required should be taken from the roster for the work as it became available.

One of the important things in respect of this debate is that waterside workers should be afforded an opportunity to state their case to the Australian public. I am perfectly satisfied that they have a good case and that they will be backed, not only by the Labour Party, but by every trade union organization from one end of Australia to the other. A few years ago the present Treasurer, when we were dealing with a report on the waterfront industry, said thai the shipowners were the worst group of employers in Australia. The late William Morris Hughes, also referring to shipowners, said that they never ceased being pirates. I am appealing to the reasonable members of this Parliament to stand up for the waterside workers when unjustified attacks are being made upon them by foreign shipowners.

Mr. BURY(Wentworth) [3.48].- The speech of the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) was notable mainly, not for what he said, but for what he left out. In any complicated industry with a great tangle of cases, it is always possible to pick out a few cases which might appear reasonable at first sight. But, granting that some cases are reasonable, I point out that what he completely omitted to mention was the pattern which has developed over the past few months in Sydney and Melbourne, a pattern specially designed by Communists to disrupt Australia's overseas trade. One thing that the honorable member for East Sydney did say which was ridiculous was that be thought that the unions had acted as they should act. In other words, his speech is tantamount to giving them complete support, without any regard whatsoever to the true interests of Australia.

The honorable member was challenged to say where he stood in relation to the secret ballot. I suppose there is no doubt that he would like to get rid of it as soon as possible, because the secret ballot is the main way to disarm the Communists and the hooligans whom they use for the purposes of intimidation. One of the cargoes most affected by trouble on the waterfront is perishable cargo. Taking the case of apples and pears, the shipping season for this fruit begins about mid-March and continues until early June. Planning for this cargo starts about September. Large numbers of ships have to be organized and assembled at different points at different times. It is most important that the good's should arrive in good condition in about twelve different overseas ports. It is important that shipments arrive regularly. If they arc disrupted, there are gluts in the supply of apples and pears to our markets. When shipping banks up, gluts occur, even if the fruit reaches the market in good condition. Success in marketing apples and pears depends on shipping flowing steadily at the right time. This is no trifling matter, as I can illustrate by pointing out that these stoppages threaten the marketing of about 8,000,000 cases of fruit worth about 30s. a case to the grower, or a total of approximately £12,000,000.

What happens if there i congestion on the wharfs at Sydney? The delays spread. Ships leave late for Hobart and bank up there. The vessel " Port Wellington ", for instance, was held up for three days for completely frivolous reasons. In many instances, no reason at all is given until a walk-off actually occurs. When a ship is held up for three or four days, the next ship is delayed, and so the port becomes congested. The delays spread to successive ships and probably later vessels are given only two or three gangs instead of five or six. In this way, the hold-ups extend into many other trades.

Disruptions have occurred also in trade with our new, developing market for meat in America. This represents one of the most promising export earners for Australia, because the demand for meat is high in America. However, currently, there are not enough ships to lift the meat within the required time. In some instances, this trade has been held up for about two weeks. re ship "Port Aylmer" was provided specifically to carry Australian meat to the east coast of the United States of America. An important shipment carried by that vessel was held up for four days. The only reason for this was that the shipowners were suddenly confronted with a demand that the strength of the gang engaged in moving the meat from railway trucks to the slings, which for years had been six men, be increased to eight. In the end, the size of the gang came back to six men, but the ship was held up for four days. Numerous other illustrations can be given. The vessel " Cap Corrientes " has just been held up for seven days. So it goes on.

The honorable member for East Sydney may take up one or two important cases - serious cases - and some may have reason in them. But these do not add up to grounds for the calculated hold-ups and distortions of our Australian trade pattern that have occurred. The honorable member suggested that this dispute was directed entirely at the overseas shipowners and their profits. What are the facts about this? Every stoppage, every increase in congestion, and all the delays - these become progressive - have effects which extend far beyond the individual dispute in each instance. Those effects are quite apart from general hold-ups in port. All the extra costs incurred are taken into account when freight rates are fixed. Those costs have to be taken into account. The costs of these upsets perpetrated by the Communistdominated unions on the waterfront are reflected in freight charges. What happens as a result? What do these increased freight costs mean to Australian exporters and individual farmers? They mean lower returns, and this means lower incomes for farmers and lover wages all round, as well as a general increase in the overseas exchange burden for Australia. The truth is that the people who, by their contemptible conduct, aim a blow at Australia's overseas trade in fact aim a blow at the standard of living, not of overseas shipowners, but of their fellow Australians. Any one who takes the trouble to follow the process through logically must inevitably be forced to the same conclusion.

Unfortunately, the wharfs have become the weeping ulcer of the Australian economy. A smooth flow of exports and adherence to promised delivery dates are vital to the development of new markets. The leaders of the Australian Labour Party often talk very gaily and glibly about the development of new markets and the promotion of Australia's exports, and they do not hesitate to blame the Government on the ground that it does not do A, B or C. Let the leaders of the Labour Party look at the true position and consider the damage inflicted on Australia's overseas trade by the conduct of the Communist-dominated unions whose activities are so ardently supported in every detail by the honorable member for East Sydney.

The present situation on the waterfront is very difficult for the Commonwealth to deal with, for the Commonwealth has only very limited powers under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Where does the Australian Labour Party stand on this issue? There was some mumbling among honorable members opposite when the honorable member for Bruce suggested that they were bitterly opposed to the secret ballot. In our political life, the secret ballot has meant emancipation and the development of our modern political system, because it has assured the right of every one to express his opinion without fear of intimidation by organized gangs. One who, I believe, is the crown prince among Opposition members is to speak later, Sir. What does he think about this issue? His views are very important because eventually, no doubt, he will dispose of his elderly colleagues and take charge. What does he think about this problem of the waterfront? Would he proceed to expand Australia's exports by supporting the kind of conduct that we see at present on the waterfront? We have every right to know what he would do, because the present conduct on the waterfront is weighing down and dragging back Australia's export trade to an enormous degree.

Mr. E.JAMES HARRISON (Blaxland) [3.58]. - Mr. Deputy Speaker, this is not a matter that we should discuss with heat. To a degree, the remarks of the honorable member for Wentworth (Mr. Bury) have some merit. He was correct when he said that the matter that we are now discussing has an important bearing on the Australian economy in the way that he outlined. For that reason, we on this side of the chamber are pleased to have this discussion. Surely it is remarkable that a supporter of a government that has been in office for more than thirteen years charges that government with being incapable of providing the kind of industrial legislation that will bring peace to an industry. The honorable member for Bruce (Mr. Snedden) talked about secret ballots. Let me tell him straight away that the policy of the Australian Labour Party provides for secret ballots. In point of fact, Mr. Fitzgibbon was elected by a secret ballot. So we look beyond mere secret ballots to find the cause of the present trouble.

I say right at the outset that I was amazed at the attitude displayed by the honorable member for Bruce. He asked us to look at the things that the waterside workers are striking for. He said that they struck for higher margins during the very week when that issue was before the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. He said that they asked for long-service leave at the very time when the issue was before the commission for decision. Is it not strange that the honorable member for Bruce, who well knows what arbitration means in this country, should base his argument on these matters, when he knows that this Government's advocate went before that same commission and spoke against the Waterside Workers Federation and every other union in Australia? I shall quote some of that gentleman's remarks. This was a Queen's Counsel, speaking for the Government and for this Minister, on 6th February, 1963, the fourth day of the hearing -

In so far as there may be any suggestion that the Commission is being invited to say formally that its decision would have any kind of applicator) in any other award, the Commonwealth strongly opposes any such suggestion.

Tn so far as the Commission is invited to say at this stage that the Commission's decision would have prima facie effect or could be given prima facie significance in other awards, the Commonwealth would strongly oppose that course.

So the Commonwealth at that stage, through Queen's Counsel representing this Minister and this Government, invited every union in Australia to go out and fight its own case for margins, how it could and how it would.
Mr. McMahon.- Not how it could and how it would.

Mr. E.JAMES HARRISON.- Yes, how it could and how it would. That obviously follows from the language used by the Government's representative. And don't forget this: Towards the conclusion of the hearing the same Queen's Counsel, speaking for the same Minister and the same government, said this -
For example, the Commonwealth would certainly regard it as a bad thing if a wage increase were to disturb the present stability of prices and costs.
So we find that this Government, through its representative, has invited the kind of agitation that is going on on the waterfront to-day for increased margins and increased rates of pay generally.
Mr. Jess.- -Rubbish! You don't believe that yourself.
Mr. Cockle.- You should not believe it.

Mr. E.JAMES HARRISON.- I repeat that the Government invited this kind of agitation. I knew at the time the submissions were made by the Commonwealth Government's representative that they were calculated to invite every other union to follow the same course as that followed by the Waterside Workers Federation.

The Government's representative also asked that any decision arrived at should not be used as a basis for deciding other cases, lt asked that the commission should not express its decision in terms of a formula. This was the very negation of the Government's argument presented in 1957 in this House. It would have done the honorable member for Bruce and other honorable members opposite a lot of good to sit in at the hearings of the commission and listen to the kind of argument adduced in that case. If they want the transcript I can tell them that I have all of it in my possession.

Then the honorable member for Bruce asked: Why this terrible trouble in Sydney and Melbourne? He went on to deal with the situation in 1961-62. Honorable members will recall that when we had the stevedoring industry legislation before us the Minister suggested that there was something different about Sydney and Melbourne. But why should Sydney and Melbourne be different from everywhere else?
Mr. McMahon.- They are under Communist control.

Mr. E.JAMES HARRISON.- That is the only answer the Minister has, and that is what is leading this country into trouble. Instead of this Government and the Minister facing realities on the waterfront, they can think only in terms of communism.
Mr. Cockle.- What would you fellows do about it?

Mr. E.JAMES HARRISON. - You will see before very long, because we will be over on that side doing it. The Minister said at that time that Sydney and Melbourne were different from other ports, but what did the commission do yesterday? Even as recently as yesterday the commission could not be united on the subject of placing a ban on the whole waterfront.
Mr. McMahon.- It was not the commission.

Mr. E.JAMES HARRISON. - All right, the Commonwealth Industrial Court. The court could not be unanimous. One member of it said that the ban should apply only to Sydney, but the other two members of the court, constituting a majority, disagreed with the Minister and said that all waterside workers should be in the same category. Let us have a look at the position in Sydney and Melbourne. I am reading from the report of the Australian Stevedoring Industry Authority for the year ended 30th June, 1962. At page 21 we find this information -

Waterside workers at most ports worked shorter hours and earned less in wages. Average weekly hours worked fell by 10 per cent, between 1960/61 and 1961/62. Average weekly wages declined by 6i per cent.
Mr. McMahon.- That is wrong.

Mr. E.JAMES HARRISON.- This was the year referred to by the honorable member for Bruce when he paid a tribute to the continuity of effort of waterside workers, and in that year they got for their magnificent effort a reduction in their average weekly earnings of 6i per cent. That appears from the Australian Stevedoring Industry Authority's own report. The Minister says it is wrong. Well, all Lean do is quote from the official report. When the honorable member for Bruce asks what is the trouble in Sydney and Melbourne, let me refer him to the following comment on the same page of the same report: -
While gross earnings fell on average by 18/4d. per week the averages at Sydney and Melbourne fell by £2 and £3 respectively.

There is your reason for the trouble in Sydney and Melbourne! In the year in which all waterside workers were good boys, in which they responded to the Government's demand and did everything required of them, we find that a group of workers in one port suffered a reduction of £2 a week in average earnings, while another group in another port lost £3 a week. No other workers in Australia were asked to accept such losses, and certainly the workers in this turbulent industry should not have had to accept them. These are the facts. They can be found in the reports of the Government's own authority, and in the transcript of proceedings of the court and the commission before which the Government has been represented.

I agree with the honorable member for Wentworth that this kind of thing should not go on, but after thirteen years of office it is quite obvious that this Government will never find the answer to the trouble on the waterfront. When it resorts to laying the blame at the door of the Communists, it burkes the issue and runs away from the real problems confronting it. It is all very well for the boys who represent country electorates to interject. I ask them and all other honorable members opposite why workers in Sydney and Melbourne should, because of automation, suffer a reduction of £2 or £3 a week in average earnings and be expected to accept these losses without a fight?
Mr. Cockle.- Do you believe in the arbitration court?

Mr. E.JAMES HARRISON.- I believe in justice - don't worry on that score. I say that if employees of the Commonwealth Railways, who are also concerned with the important transport industry, can be assured of a guaranteed wage and continuity of employment, then the waterside worker, who is also playing his part in the transport industry which means so much to Australia, should also have these guarantees. Until this Government faces the fact that a waterside worker is entitled to the same benefits, protection and nourishment as are workers in other industries, we will not have peace on the waterfront.
Mr. DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr. Mackinnon).- Order! The honorable member's time has expired.

Mr. BARNES(McPherson) [4.8].- The two speakers we have heard from the front bench of the Opposition side of the House have shown us that they are completely in support of the waterfront strikes, of this lawlessness on the waterfront that is taking such a toll of our community. They have shown that they are just as irresponsible as these people on the waterfront. I was completely unimpressed by the very weak arguments of the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward), who tried desperately to justify these strikes by going back to the time of Mr. Hughes in his effort to find something to use to bolster his arguments.

The honorable member for Wentworth (Mr. Bury) has stressed the importance to Australia of its export trade. He mentioned the apple and pear growing industry, of which I have some knowledge in my own electorate. This industry is greatly influenced by seasonal conditions. It must try to export its products at a time when they will attract the best prices on overseas markets. In this respect we in Queensland have an advantage of a few weeks over the southern parts of Australia, from which apples and pears are also exported. If we have a hold-up for one week on the waterfront, the primary producers, who have battled with drought, hail and other adversities, lose their markets. They are likely to lose the whole profit of twelve months' work because of some irresponsibility on the waterfront which receives the support of Opposition members. I would like to read a statement made by the chairman of the Federal Exporters Oversea Transport Committee, which is of vital interest to every primary producer and every exporter. He said -

This Committee is seriously disturbed at present industrial conditions on the Australian waterfront, and the adverse effect that these cannot fail to have on the interests of exporters and producers and the national economy.
The disputes and issues involved should surely be the subject of arbitration, and not unilateral action on the part of the Waterside Workers' Federation and its members.

Interruptions in the work of loading and discharging vessels, in addition to damaging export markets, have, of course, a direct impact on the cost of the shipping services, and in the end affect freight rates.

The policy of this Government is to reduce costs, and freight is one of the biggest factors in costs in Australia. But our friends on the opposite side of the House do all they can to egg the waterside workers on to further industrial lawlessness.
