The waterside workers have never in the history of waterfront employment enjoyed wages and working conditions as good as those they have had in recent years. Until recently we had a record period of peace on the waterfront. We know who is behind this recent lawlessness. It is the Communist element in the waterfront unions. I know that Opposition members will not believe this, but they will have to bring themselves up to date.

The Government introduced court controlled ballots to give the rank and file members control of the affairs of the unions. Opposition members opposed the introduction of these ballots. They support the idea of secret ballots, but they do not like court controlled ballots, because the Communists do not like them. The 36 men who decide the defence policy of the Australian Labour Party also decide this issue. But, thanks to court-controlled ballots, a nonCommunist was elected to the executive of the Waterside Workers Federation. This shocked the Communists and these strikes are designed to discredit him. The alleged purpose of the strikes - this also is lawless - is to support claims for increased margins, increased annual leave and other leave conditions. These issues, of course, should be decided by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. However, these people do not want arbitration; they want disruption in our community.

In its efforts to ensure that the rank and file unionists receive justice, the Government has amended the conciliation and arbitration legislation. This does not suit the Communists. Most of our unions abide by arbitration, but those unions that are Communist-controlled do not. The Communists do not care about the average rank and file worker. The workers lose their pay when they are on strike, but the union secretaries still receive their salaries. This suits the Communist bosses. My friend, the honorable member for Bruce (Mr. Snedden), mentioned a stop-work meeting which was held in the Sydney stadium to support Fidel Castro. The Communist bosses of the Waterside Workers Federation concern themselves with such matters rather than with better conditions for the rank and file members.

Penalties are provided for breaches of our civil laws and criminal laws. Why, therefore, should penalties not be provided for breaches of our arbitration laws? These unorthodox strikes are anti-social and penalties should be provided to deal with them. We know that if Labour were ever returned to office we would have more and more strikes, because Labour is pledged to remove the penalties for breaches of the arbitration laws and to remove the right to hold court-controlled ballots. What sort of chaos would we have if Labour ever became the Government? It is most important that all primary producers who are represented in this place by Labour members should note that Labour supports the kind of lawlessness that leads to increased freight rates and increased costs.

The honorable member for East Sydney mentioned the conditions that caused some strikes. He went back about twelve months. Perhaps I could mention some instances that are right up to date. In Sydney, on 3rd April last, between 2 p.m. and 3.10 p.m., 243 members of the mechanical branch walked off 45 vessels in protest against the failure to secure increased margins. Between 2 p.m. and 3.30 p.m. 384 men were dismissed for refusing to re-form into manual gangs. A total of 191 men were discharged as being unemployable. The key men had gone and there was no work. At 3.45 p.m. waterside workers required to work all the time refused to accept meal money. Between 4 p.m. and 6 p.m. 413 men were dismissed and 123 men were discharged as being unemployable. At 8.15 p.m. the only member of the mechanical branch employed on the evening shift walked off the job. A total of 22 vessels was involved in the refusals to break up gangs and to accept meal money.

The honorable member for East Sydney had to go back twelve months, but this is up to date. I have lists of other instances of this irresponsible attitude in this vital indus try. I think it is time that the Australian people took full notice of this attitude.

Mr. WHITLAM(Werriwa) [4.18].- Tha honorable member for McPherson (Mr. Barnes) is unfortunately typical of so many primary producers and of their representatives in this place who attribute all Australia's trading problems to the waterside workers. His favorite gimmick for correcting this position is to have a secret ballot in the Waterside Workers Federation. Under the rules approved by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the Waterside Workers Federation has always had secret ballots. There has never been an allegation of irregularity in those ballots. If there had been any irregularity, it would have been open to anybody in the federation, under the Chifley Government's 1949 legislation, to move to have a court-controlled ballot, as it is called. Attempts have been made in the federation and in many other unions to muster the minute percentage of the members which under the 1951 Holt legislation suffices to displace the rules of the union as approved by the Arbitration Commission and to substitute a postal ballot conducted by the Electoral Office. I aim to bring a bit of proportion into this argument. Listening to government speakers up to this stage, one would think than Australia was a strike-ridden country, that the waterside workers were responsible for most of the lost man-hours in Australia, and that the Waterside Workers Federation was responsible for the inefficiency that we all know occurs on the waterfront.

I will refute the first allegation, Sir, by quoting from the editorial of the " Financial Review" of 11th October last. It quotes figures for the eight years ended 1960 given in the International Labour Office's "Year Book of Labour Statistics". It gives the number of working days lost in comparable countries over those eight years and then relates them to the Australian population. In that period Australia lost 6,000,000 working days. With our population, the United States of America would have lost 13,000,000 working days; the United Kingdom would have lost 6,000,000; Japan would have lost 4,500,000; Italy would have lost nearly 9,000,000; France would have lost 5,500,000; and Canada would have lost 9,000,000. It appears, therefore, that trading countries comparable with Australia, in general, lost proportionately more man hours through strikes between 1952 and 1960 than Australia did.

The next allegation is that the waterside workers are responsible for most of the man-hours lost. Last financial year 358,124 man-hours were lost through wharf stoppages. In the previous year 1,193,000 man-hours were lost through wharf stoppages. So far in this financial year the figure would be somewhere between those two figures. Of the man-hours lost in Australia, the greatest number is due to this Government's measures of November, 1960. If we assume - this is not unreasonable - that 50,000 fewer people were in employment throughout the years since that date than would have been in employment but for those measures, we find that 200,000,000 man-hours were lost in the two years following those measures. The man-hours lost on the waterfront through the quarrels between employers and employees represent less than 1 per cent, of that total.

The final allegation is that the Waterside Workers Federation is responsible for the admittedly inefficient conditions on Australian wharfs. I go back to the analysis that was published by the Australian Stevedoring Industry Board in the first year of this Government's term of office. The board said -

The state of affairs on the Australian waterfront has become almost everyday reading. Unfortunately, there is a general misconception as to the real cause of the problem. It is convenient and usual to blame wharf labour first and last . . . There is no parallel between the degree of efficiency of labour in productive employment and the present turn-round problem. The crux of that problem lies in the nonproductive proportion of working time by which 1 in every 4 hours of employment of labour is barren of cargo movement.
From another part of this report, it appears that-
Mr. Cockle,- For what year is that?

Mr. WHITLAM.- This is the report for the year 1949-50. From another part of the report, it appears that the degree of working time which was non-productive was 29 per cent, on the waterfront in Sydney and 27 per cent, on the waterfront in Melbourne. The overall percentage has since gone up. In 1957-58 it was 35.5 per cent., and in 1961-62 it was 37.7 per cent. This is due to the fact that management on the wharfs is notoriously inefficient. The report of the board for the year 1949-50 explains that in these terms -
At the root of waterfront problems are the outmoded methods and techniques of management . . .
The present position represents a challengewhich responsible management cannot afford to ignore - for a reconsideration of the approach to, and conduct of, stevedoring affairs.

In January, 1952, Mr. Basten made a report on this matter. He pointed out that there was no direct contact or sense of respect between management and labour on the waterfront. As this was the only casual employment in Australia, he said - it is not to be imagined that the man can feel he has any contractual relation with the succession of stevedoring companies who have been his employers and if he concludes that the employer in the industry is a legal fiction he may be very close to the truth. This is, indeed, casual employment and it is not surprising that the relations between employer and employee continue to be weak and mistrustful.

In the subsequent eleven years there has been no legislation which has made employment on the wharfs any less casual. The former Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. Harold Holt) used to be much more frank about the position. He said this in 1956, when anticipating the report of the Tait committee -

It is a matter of unhappy notoriety that our waterfront performance is chronically bad. Performance is poor. Industrial relations are bad and have been bad for generations. The stevedoring industry has been rightly described more than once as a turbulent industry . . .

I say quite frankly that, in my own judgment, the employers made a great mistake in not negotiating an agreement during the last dispute, when the opportunity offered. There was then an opportunity for the negotiation of a satisfactory agreement which might have been the beginning of an improved relationship.

A couple of months later the Tait committee brought in its report. It pointed out that the rise in stevedoring costs in Australia was not due to, and could not be accounted for by, any conduct of the employees; but was caused by the employers who did not have the incentive to be efficient. It said that they could always pass on their costs; that half the stevedoring companies were subsidiaries. of foreign shipping companies; and that another quarter of them were subsidiaries of interstate shipping companies.
Mr. Cockle.-Who said that?

Mr. WHITLAM.- The Tait committee, which was appointed by this Government. The fact that the Government has not carried out its recommendations does not mean that the Government can refute its findings. The committee said that the majority of stevedoring companies were subsidiaries of foreign shipping companies and that they passed on their costs. The " Sydney Morning Herald ", in commenting on this aspect, said -
The shipping industry does not have the same incentives to be efficient as other big industries.
So we should not complain about the waterside workers only, or principally, on the score of costs.

A couple of months ago I heard, in New Guinea, that it costs more to bring cocoa from Lae to Sydney than from Ghana to Sydney. The cocoa is unloaded at the same port, so one must blame not the Sydney waterside workers but the foreign shippers for Lae cocoa costing more than Ghana cocoa. Again, we know that where there is efficient management, such as the Broken Hill Proprietary Company Limited provides at Port Kembla and Newcastle, stevedoring costs are lower. In the Estimates debate last year I quoted a letter which the chairman of directors of that company sent to me. He said -

Although we are not aware of actual stevedoring costs in the United Kingdom and Europe we doubt whether they, are less than those applying at the Newcastle Steelworks wharf or at the Port Kembla Inner Harbour products berth. Also we are of the opinion that our loading rates at these points would compare favourably with those in the United Kingdom and Europe.

Where there is efficient management, Australian stevedoring costs are lower than those of other exporting countries. In other words, where there is efficient management we can compete with any other people in the world.

This Parliament has power, under the Constitution, to pass laws with respect to trade and commerce with other countries and between the States. If we desire, we can pass workers' compensation legislation for the stevedoring industry. Per years the

Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. McMahon) has been telling us that he is seeking information on compensable accidents, but he never publishes the information. We can pass laws to provide for long-service leave. We have done that. We can pass laws to provide for higher pensions for waterside workers. That was done at Rotterdam, the biggest port in the world, by a Labour Minister in The Netherlands Government only three years ago. Thirty-five different authorities operate Australia's 100 ports. By co-operation with the State Governments we can have an efficient stevedoring industry with wharfs and machinery operated by a joint statutory body and men employed by that body. Such a body could not fail to be more effective than the present diverse authorities, trusts, boards and companies. In other words, by a combination of Commonwealth and State powers we can ensure that Australian maritime terminal facilities are in such hands as our railway terminal facilities have always been.
Mr. DEPUTY SPEAKER.-Order! The honorable member's time has expired.

Mr. McMAHON(Lowe - Minister for Labour and National Service) [4.28]. - Mr. Deputy Speaker, as I understood the honorable member for Bruce (Mr. Snedden), who initiated this debate, he wished, first of all, to direct our attention or public attention to what was happening on the Sydney and Melbourne waterfronts and, more importantly, to find out where the Australian Labour Party stood in respect of the strikes that are now taking place. In June of last year I had a conference with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Waterside Workers Federation in which they agreed that it was preferable to settle their disputes by resort to conciliation and, if conciliation failed, then by resort to arbitration. That was an undertaking given to me by the federation and by the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

For several months we had what may be regarded as an enviable record. I will not give all the details, but the loss of man hours was 10,000 in February last, 16,000 in January, 3,000 in December and 5,890 in November. This means that immediately following those discussions there was a lull on the waterfront and the number of strikes and stoppages was reduced to a minimum.

But I am prepared to forecast - I have not yet got the figures - 'that last month, the period about which we are talking, man hours lost will amount to more than 100,000 and will possibly be as high as 125,000. This indicates what I have tried to point out to the House for several years, namely, that these stoppages need not take place. They are engineered by groups of the Waterside Workers Federation, and particularly by the Sydney and Melbourne branches. My colleague asked: What is the cause of these disputes? The simple fact is that nobody can ever ascertain thencause.

I have here a list of about 30 disputes that have occurred in the last few days. Men ceased work on the " Shun Wing ", which was loading scrap iron, on 12th March following a demand for 2s. 6d. an hour extra and provision of fresh milk twice a day, safety boots, soap and towels. That was the cause of that dispute, but in many cases the waterside workers do not state the cause of their dispute first and try to settle the matter by conciliation and arbitration. Instead they walk off the job and later make known the cause of their dispute. On 13th March, 76 men engaged on the day shift ceased work in circumstances similar to those I have already referred to. On the same day the " Cape Grafton " was loading scrap metal. Fifty-two men engaged on the evening shift failed to commence work following similar demands. Disputes arose on the Melbourne waterfront over manning schedules on the "Iberic", the "Straat Cook", the "Argyllshire", the "Middlesex ", the " Thorsgaard " and the " State of Travancore-Cochin ".

The pattern that has emerged from these recent disturbances shows that it is difficult to work out a pattern of disputes. The branch officials are not permitting the arbitration system to work, despite the promise made to me by the federation in June last year. Another important matter that must be recognized by the House is that in relation to two recent disputes, the disputes arose while officers of the federation were negotiating with the shipowners. That did not matter a boot to the executive of the Sydney branch. It pulled the men out. The federation did not know and the Australian Council of Trade Unions was not aware of the dispute or of the nature of it.

Plenty of evidence exists to show that these disputes are intended to continue for some considerable time. Any one looking at the latest copy of " Branch News " published by the Sydney branch of the federation - I have a copy here - will see a statement by the Sydney branch executive that it intends to p jil on strikes whenever it thinks there is some justification for its action. There can be no doubt in the world that in Melbourne and Sydney these people are determined, if they can, to destroy the system of industrial arbitration as we know it in this country. I have no doubt that their intention is to destroy arbitration - to avoid a board of reference and to have direct access to Mr. Justice Ashburner - or, if they feel like it, to obtain their objectives by direct means. It does not matter what the Opposition says about this matter. It may pooh-pooh the claim that the Communists are in control in the ports of Sydney and Melbourne. The fact is that they are in control. Everybody knows that the objective of the Communist leadership in this country is to disorganize and disrupt not only our international trade but also our interstate trade. The Communists are achieving their objectives - against the wishes of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and certainly without its benediction. Who benefits from the losses on the waterfront? The first thing we must ask ourselves is: What do these losses mean to the men themselves? The honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) referred to what had happened with regard to working hours on the waterfront. He referred to what had happened with regard to weekly hours but he failed to point out that during the years 1953-54 to 1961-62- despite what Tom Nelson said in a letter to the " Sydney Morning Herald " on 2nd April - the average weekly earnings on the waterfront in Australia had increased from £16 6s. 3d. to £19 2s. lOd. In the same period weekly average gross earnings increased to £21 10s. 7d. I am glad that the waterside workers are getting those amounts. I would like to see the men get more and they could get more if the Sydney and Melbourne branches did not consistently pull on these futile and irresponsible stoppages.
Mr. Ward.- What happened to the shipowners' profits in the same period?

Mr. McMAHON.- I am answering the honorable member's question. I have told him what is happening in terms of average wages and gross payments despite the fact, as stated by the honorable member for Blaxland (Mr. E. James Harrison), that in Sydney there has been a fall of £2 and in Melbourne a fall of £3. If this is so it proves the point made by my colleague. If the earnings of waterside workers elsewhere have increased so substantially while those of waterside workers in Communistdominated ports have fallen by £2 and £3 a week, surely it proves that there is no necessity for those losses and that the men themselves have been persecuted by their Communist leaders.
Mr. £.James Harrison. - That was in your good year.

Mr. McMAHON.- It does not matter when it was. If the men in Sydney and Melbourne have lost those amounts in recent years while the men in other ports have received increases, it can be ascribed only to one cause and that is that the federation has lost control of Sydney under Tom Nelson and of Melbourne under its branch officials. This state of affairs cannot be in the interests of the men. Can it be in the interests of the trade union movement? I hesitate to say this, but only to-day the Australian Council of Trade Unions has called the federation to Melbourne to discuss the disputes.
Mr. Calwell.- How do you know?

Mr. McMAHON.- I have read about it in the newspapers. You are always full of information. You should have found out about this before. You are always a little behind in your information. Read to-day's newspapers and you will find out.
Mr. Calwell.- I did not talk about the Menzies-Chifley Government.

Mr. McMAHON.-I regret that mistake but you should have been honoured that I mentioned Mr. Chifley. I certainly did not try to misrepresent the position by claiming that it was Mr. Chifley who introduced the legislation. Mine was a slip of the tongue; yours was a slip of the mind.

It must be recognized that these strikes are contrary to the interests of the trade union movement. As my friend the honorable member for Wentworth (Mr. Bury) said, the disruption of our trade is against the interests of all Australians. If the present practice in Sydney and Melbourne continues inevitably there will be a slowing up of trade. This will be followed by a slowing up of manufacturing and the situation will work its way through to the employees and to all sections of industry. As the honorable member for Mcpherson (Mr. Barnes) said, this state of affairs could lead to disastrous losses by some sections of primary producers, particularly at the moment those people producing apples and pears for export. The trade unions have a big responsibility to take action to get the waterside workers back to work and to keep them working consistently. One of the reasons why we initiated this debate was to develop public opinion about what these men are doing to Australia's future. We believed that if we could make public opinion sufficiently hostile to the officials, not the men, of the Waterside Workers Federation in time the men would take control and stop the futile acts in which their officials are involving them to-day.

What are the remedies in this case? Let us consider the remedies which are available under the law of the land. Two major remedies are available, first, against the men themselves, and, secondly, against the Waterside Workers Federation. The men themselves already have lost over £300,000 in attendance money. This money would be in their pockets but for the fact that Nelson and his cohorts, his Communist friends, have pulled them out on strike, deprived them of their day's pay and also of a total of £300,000 in attendance money. The men themselves must realize that these losses have been caused deliberately by the people whom the Labour Party to-day is supporting in the House. First the honor,able member for East Sydney and then, in somewhat muted voice, the honorable member for Blaxland supported the federation's activities. Under the influence of the federation and the Labour Party, the men have lost a very large amount of money. Secondly, yesterday a general ban of indefinite duration was imposed by the Commonwealth Industrial Court on wharf stoppages in all Australian ports. When stating his views yesterday Mr. Justice Spicer said -

The reasons for the new order were strengthened by the conduct of the Waterside Workers Federation over the past three years and re-affirmed by material in the union's publications of the intention to engage in industrial action to obtain certain claims.
Not arbitration, not conciliation, but industrial action! Mr. Justice Dunphy remarked -
Orders restricting stoppages had proved effective in 99 per cent, of cases. A lot of trade union leaders and trade unionists have a respect for law and order and they uphold the Court's decision.

But not so the gentleman of the Waterside Workers Federation. If these prohibitions are not observed they are defying the law and even the prohibition of the court itself. The steamship owners can make an application for a penalty under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. These are the legal remedies.

At this point I want to direct attention, not so much to the legal remedies which are available, as to certain other important factors. The first is that some months ago, when a election was held for the office of general secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation, the men did not vote for Tom Nelson, who stood as a Communist candidate, but for Mr. Charlie Fitzgibbon, who stood as an Australian Labour Party or rank and file candidate. When Charlie Fitzgibbon was elected the first person to claim credit for this was the incredible gentleman from Melbourne, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Calwell).
Mr.Calwell. - It was not incredible. I supported him from the beginning. I urged him to stand.
Mr.McMAHON.- The honorable gentleman had nothing to do with Fitzgibbon^ victory.
Mr. Calwell.- You are becoming sillier every day.

Mr. McMAHON.- 'If the honorable gentleman did have anything to do with Fitzgibbon^ victory, what is he doing now? Why does he not give Charlie Fitzgibbon some support to help him overcome the trouble which he is having with other federation officials? Why does not the honorable gentleman stand on his hind legs and be counted, and when the next election is being held in the federation state that the Labour Party supports the rank and file candidate? One way in which the waterside workers themselves can come to grips with this problem is by a ballot.

The second important factor is that the A.C.T.U. must now realize that the activities of the Sydney and Melbourne branches of the Federation are destroying our overseas trade and preventing us from earning export income. If the A.C.T.U. plays its part - a part it can play because of its great political influence as one of the great institutions of this country - I am certain that, through the ballot-box and through the activities of the trade union movement, there can be a drastic reduction in time lost on the waterfront, with immense benefit to Australia, and the destruction of the Communist element on the Sydney waterfront.

Mr.CALWELL (Melbourne- Leader of the Opposition) [4.44]. - The Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. McMahon), as usual, made a mess of his case. He adduced nothing by way of solid argument in support of the case which was advanced by the honorable member for Bruce (Mr. Snedden), who did not do much good for himself either. He rehashed all the old stereotyped arguments, the halftruths and the complete falsehoods, and carried on the smear campaign that is always directed against the waterside workers by honorable members on the Government side, who support the shipowners.

The waterfront industry is a turbulent one because of the casual nature of the work. It is the only casual industry remaining in Australia. The Chifley Government did more than any government before it, and certainly more than the present Government, to decasualize the industry. This Government has not continued the work of decasualization which was commenced by the Chifley Government. In addition, there is the problem of mechanization on the waterfront. The honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) touched the centre of the problem when he said that over 1,000 fewer men were employed in this industry this year than was the case last year. Any one who knows anything about the waterfront has only to consider what has happened in recent times to appreciate the truth of the honorable member's statement. The bulk handling of sugar has thrown hundreds of watersiders out of work at all the Queensland sugar ports from Cairns to Bundaberg and even to Gladstone. The bulk loading of sugar concentrate at Townsville has thrown watersiders out of work, as has the bulk loading of coal at Gladstone. The roll-on-roll-off ships - the " Princess of Tasmania" and the "Bass Trader" which operate from Melbourne to Devonport - both have thrown out of work persons engaged on the waterfront and in all the ancillary occupations. When the " Empress of Australia" is completed more watersiders will be thrown out of work in Sydney and Hobart. Now the Government proposes to extend the roll-on-roll-off system to Queensland.

What has the Government done to help any of the people who have been thrown out of work? It has merely said, "Let them find other work". During the last election campaign Labour proposed that a special section should be created within the Department of Labour and National Service to train men displaced from jobs for other work. We do not regard displaced Australian workers as persons who should be discarded and thrown aside. We are not interested in shipowners' profits, as Government supporters are. We believe that people who are thrown out of work have the same right to live and the same right to raise their families as has any other section of the community. Whether the men are watersiders or any one else, if they have been affected by mechanization or automation they are worthy of consideration. They have the right to live. We defend that right. But not a word was said by any honorable member on the Government side about that aspect, although a good deal was said in criticism of the watersiders. Government supporters claim that the watersiders will not do this and will not do that, but the number of jobs on the waterfront is decreasing steadily and continuously and the watersiders claim that if their colleagues are being thrown out of work because of the increased use of mechanical aids then more men should be included in each gang so that the process of elimination will be eased somewhat. However, the shipowners have said that that cannot be done.

When the men take strike action they are penalized under the provisions of the exist ing legislation. The Government claims that they should be penalized. When there is a strike-free period the Government says, "The workers love us so much that they work for us, so we must be the best possible government which could be elected ". However, when industrial turmoil created by the inability of the shipowners and the Government to understand the workers' needs results in strikes the Government says, " It is all due to a Communist conspiracy ".

Let us consider the position in Melbourne. The watersiders in Melbourne have an Australian Democratic Labour Party president and a Communist secretary, both of whom have been unbeatable in recent elections. The committee there is made up of Communists and Labour men, as is the case also in New South Wales. There are Communists holding office in many unions and they are there because of the workers' discontent with prevailing conditions. Wherever men and women in industry are satisfied that they are getting a fair deal, Communist influence is negligible or dwindling; it is certainly not increasing. The member for Bruce said that the Waterside Workers Federation is Communistcontrolled. It is nothing of the sort. There are more Labour people in it than anything else, and even some Australian Democratic Labour Party supporters, who are certainly not Communists.

The honorable member then had the effrontery to say that some of the 36 men who constitute the conference of the Australian Labour Party are Communists. That is a complete falsehood. There is not a vestige of truth in that statement and there is nothing to support it, but the old smear is cast over Labour men and their characters. The honorable member for Bruce talked a lot of nonsense about the meeting held in Melbourne in support of Castro. It would not have been held for that purpose.
