AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL UNIVERSITY BILL 1963.
Second Reading.
Debate resumed from 28th March (vide page 160), on motion by Sir Robert Menzies -
That the bill be now read a second time.

Mr. BEAZLEY(Fremantle) [5.25].- The Opposition supports this measure. It will be recalled that some six years ago the Australian National University was given control - as one of its scientific research activities - of the Mount Stromlo Observatory, which for many years was the Commonwealth Observatory at Mount Stromlo. The Government has, I think, come up against the problem that the Australian National University, in conducting its astronomical scientific research, may have to acquire, by resumption, various sites in the Commonwealth, and such acts of acquisition could be the subject of legal challenge. The Commonwealth has no power over universities, except in its own territories. Nothing in the Constitution suggests that there is a power to conduct universities, and such a challenge against the Commonwealth might be successful. However, the Commonwealth has power to conduct astronomical and meteorological observations, and so the Prime Minister (Sir Robert Menzies) has suggested the addition of a section to the Australian National University Act, to read as follows: - 6a. The powers of the University extend to the making of astronomical and meteorological observations in any part of the Commonwealth.
The activities of the university thus rest on the statutory power of the Commonwealth over astronomical and meteorological observations.

It is tempting to turn to other fields in which one might find that Commonwealth activity was doubtful. Nothing in the Constitution says that the Commonwealth can conduct scientific and industrial research, and it seems that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization is always very careful not to resume land. It is also, perhaps, doubtful whether the Commonwealth can conduct television activities, but as a result of developments in connexion with Rippon Lea we may see some decision later with relation to such activities. But there is no doubt whatever about the Commonwealth's capacity to conduct astronomical activities.

The university has been engaging in three searches, one of which has been completed. The first search was for a site for the Mount Stromlo field station. The second was for an observatory site for major instrumental development, and that second project has apparently been enlarged to embrace the wider idea of establishing a British Commonwealth southern observatory. The report of the Australian National University for 1961 says this: -

Unexpected delays have reduced the urgency of the second project. Early in 1961 the establishment of a British Commonwealth Southern Observatory with a 120-inch reflector as the main instrument, was discussed but no conclusions have been reached. As a result, the project is presently in abeyance, an unfortunate fact in view of the important role that a Commonwealth Southern Observatory might have played - and still can play in the overall development programme for astronomy in Australia.

The Mount Stromlo astronomers feel that they must continue a vigorous search for a site for the major telescope development which is essential if Australian astronomy is to retain its present place. They have been testing various mountain sites around the Commonwealth. Nine or ten are mentioned in the 1961 report. But since the 1961 report was published the ideas concerning the British Commonwealth southern observatory have changed somewhat, and the desire of the university at the present time is not for a 120-inch telescope but for a 150-inch reflector. Professor Bok, in a paper that he submitted, had this to say -

Australian and British astronomers appear to be agreed upon the desirability of a ISO-inch Reflector as the basic instrument for the proposed British Commonwealth Southern Observatory. An instrument with an aperture of ISO inches should provide in Australia a major telescope that need not take second place to any now in the planning stage. Experience overseas has demonstrated that a 120-inch Reflector, while exceedingly useful, is rather on the small side by modern standards and, furthermore, that it is too small to permit the astronomer to observe directly at the prime focus. As a scientific investment, a ISO-inch Reflector is clearly the best buy.

The plan for a ISO-inch Reflector for Australia received strong support from the leaders in the astronomical profession, who attended the recent International Symposium on " The Galaxy and the Magellanic Clouds", held during March in Canberra and in Sydney. The President of the International Astronomical Union, Professor V. A. Ambartsumian, specifically endorsed the proposal, which has also received strong personal support from the Astronomer Royal, Sir Richard Woolley.
Honorable members will recall that Sir Richard Woolley was at one time the Commonwealth Astronomer and became Professor of Astronomy at the Australian
National University before going to the United Kingdom as Astronomer Royal. Professor Bok has made certain estimates as to cost. He said -

My personal estimate places the total cost at approximately six million pounds Australian, with seven million pounds Australian appearing to be a safe maximum. This capital expenditure will be spread over seven or eight years, with the annual expenditure initially at the rate of approximately one-quarter of a million pounds, to increase to one million pounds annually after about three years. Provisionally, equal sharing of costs by Britain and Australia seems to be called for, but it may of course be that other Commonwealth Nations, Canada or India, for example, might wish to participate in the scheme from the start.

It is certainly to be hoped that they do. While we on the Opposition side give the Government full support for the legal change that will make these astronomical activities possible, we urge the Government to try to conclude agreements with either the United Kingdom alone or with a number of other Commonwealth countries to make this work possible. We also ask the Government to ensure that the observatory, when set up, is equipped with the finest instruments it is now possible to acquire so that the work done in astronomical research in Australia will be of the highest quality.

There is one other aspect of this matter. The Prime Minister (Sir Robert Menzies), following section 31 sub-section (viii) of the Australian Constitution, is also empowering the university to undertake meteorological activities anywhere in the Commonwealth. I understand that at the moment the university has no such projects in mind, but I could be wrong in saying this. The main urgency is on the astronomical side. While the Government is conferring upon the university the legal power to carry out these activities, we hope that it will give the university the financial ability to carry out the activities in an optimum manner.

Mr. WENTWORTH(Mackellar) [5.34]. - I not only support the bill but I also find myself in very warm agreement with the remarks just made by the honorable member for Fremantle (Mr. Beazley). This may seem to be a small bill, but it deals with a subject that can be of considerable importance. I think it would be a good idea if the House took this opportunity to review some of the progress that Australian science has made in this field and to place on record its pride in the achievement of certain Australian scientists. lt is not given to a small country to lead the world in many directions, but Australia has been able to give a world lead in some directions. Perhaps the House does not realize the world importance of the work done by Australian pioneers in the field of radio astronomy. I have in mind such men as the late Dr. Pawsey, Dr. Bowen, Dr. Bolton, Mills, Christiansen and Wild. These people have opened -for the world a new window in the universe. The pioneering work was done here, and we in Australia still lead in radio astronomy. I believe that when this sort of situation emerges, it is up to us as Australians to back those who have shown by their merits and their achievements what can be done. These people deserve recognition and, more than that, they deserve support.

As we know, our progress in this field has come about through the co-operation of various instrumentalities. One would, I think, name three of them. One is the Commonwealth Observatory under the control of Dr. Bok, who has been mentioned by the honorable member for Fremantle. The second is the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, which perhaps has played the main part. The third is the University of Sydney, particularly the School of Physics.

Radio astronomy is a new science that has developed in the post-war period. It was found that in addition to the shortlength visible rays of light - the optical rays - certain objects in space emitted intense radiation at long wave lengths. We were then faced with the problem of focusing this radiation so that we could pinpoint the locations in the sky from which it was coming. The surprise finding was that the intense waves were coming not necessarily from the brightest objects in the sky. In other words, we were able to open a new window in the universe through which we could locate objects, the existence of which had not been suspected. As I said, this work was pioneered in Australia and Australia still leads in this new and vital aspect of the science of astronomy. We are receiving international recognition. The honorable member for Fremantle mentioned a conference which was held recently in Canberra and Sydney. I think the participants in that conference were impressed by the lead that Australia is giving.

We have at present two or three projects under way in this field of radio astronomy. We have had international support, financial and otherwise, in them. It is no bad thing for Australia that we are attracting from other countries support in this branch of science. We are doing big things in this field. First, I would mention the big radio telescope at Parkes. This is a big movable dish 210 feet across, which is comparable only to the Jodrell Bank instrument in Great Britain. It is better than the Jodrell Bank instrument because it has been built to finer tolerances and can use a fineness of focus which no other large instrument in this field in the world can even approach. From Parkes momentous new discoveries will probably flow. This is something in which Australia will be the focus of world attention.
Mr. Howson.- Will it do a better job than the Jodrell Bank telescope?

Mr. WENTWORTH.- Yes, it will do a much better job. Although it is not quite as big as the Jodrell Bank instrument, it has been built to much finer tolerances. From memory, the Jodrell Bank instrument has tolerances of four or five inches, but this instrument has tolerances of under half an inch and down to one-eighth of an inch. That is particularly important because it allows focussing of the 21 centimetre hydrogen line which is outside the range of the Jodrell Bank instrument. Whilst I am not competent to discuss these technicalities, from having conversations with Professor Bok and other people I know that at Parkes we have an instrument that is away ahead of anything available in this field anywhere else in the world.

Not very far from Canberra, at Hoskinstown, a very large Mills Cross is under construction. It is not yet complete. It will not be completed for a year or two. It is a fixed instrument. It has not the versatility of the Parkes instrument which is capable of traversing the whole sky, but it gives a higher degree of resolution. In certain respects it will do better work than the Parkes instrument, although in other respects it will not be able to cover the work that the Parkes instrument does. The Mills Cross is an Australian invention. We have to wait with some hope to see what this new instrument will turn up. There is every reason to believe that it will be one of mankind's most significant probes into the nature of the universe.

At Narrabri we have two instruments - a solar interferometer which is studying the sun, and the new intensity interferometer which is able to give angular diameters of the stars and, for the brightest of them, to determine their distances, their positions and their sizes. These are very important instruments, not only to Australian astronomy but to world astronomy. We have to realize that here we are really leading the field. I have mentioned the three chief sites of radio astronomy. But if we are to get the fullest value from those instruments, it is necessary that we should be able to correlate them with optical astronomy.

Very many of the radio sources are coming from objects which are too faint to be perceived by any but a very big optical telescope. Our existing telescopes are not capable of working up to the full value of the radio instruments that we already possess. For that reason, among others, we need to have a large optical telescope in Australia. I believe that the honorable member for Fremantle was perfectly correct in supporting this. I also believe that he gave correctly the technical reasons why we should be going for an instrument with a 150-inch aperture rather than one with a 120-inch aperture. As he said, it is more convenient to have the observer placed at the prime focus than to reflect the light from a mirror. Because of the physical size of the human body, and the space it occupies at the prime focus, it is desirable to have the bigger instrument.

We should thus be thinking of getting this big telescope under way. There are other reasons why we should be thinking of a big telescope besides the undoubted need for it in conjunction with our world leadership in radio astronomy. In the southern hemisphere, so far, there are no big telescopes. I think the best ones are the 74-in. instrument at Canberra and a 74-in. instrument in South Africa. That, of course, is very much less than what is available for the northern hemisphere, in many places. In many respects, the southern hemisphere is the more important and more interesting hemisphere for astronomers. The centre of the Milky Way passes over the southern zenith and not the northern zenith, and the Magellanic clouds - the closest galaxies to our Milky Way - are best observed from the southern hemisphere and not from the northern hemisphere.

For that reason, astronomers all over the world are now embarking on a programme of getting big instruments into the southern hemisphere. I understand that the United States of America has a project for an instrument in Chile and that the European astronomers have a project for an instrument in either Chile or South Africa. The British Commonwealth should think of its instrument being placed here in Australia. This is the right place for it. South Africa is no longer a member of the Commonwealth. For practical purposes, tha. leaves Australia and New Zealand. New Zealand has the attraction of having higher mountains - it is desirable to place the telescope high up, if possible, in order to minimize the atmospheric interference with observation - but as a site it suffers certainly from one defect and probably from two.

The certain defect is that it is too near the south magnetic pole and lies in the zone of auroral intensity, which interferes with observation. The probable defect is the amount of cloud cover which would be expected on a New Zealand site and which would be greater than that expected on an Australian site. Therefore, it seems that the logical thing is to place this big British Commonwealth project in Australia, particularly since Australia has, in such a significant degree, shown world leadership in the use of what is, perhaps, the most important new tool of the astronomer.

Various sites have been suggested. 1 understand that there are three that are primarily under consideration at this moment. One site is at Coonabarabran, adjacent to the 40-in. instrument that is under construction at present near Siding Spring. The second site is in Western Australia, near Mount Singleton, which is about 200 miles north-east of Perth. The Perth observatory has done excellent work in the positional field, as also has the

Sydney observatory. The third suggested site is in South Australia, on Mount Woodroffe, which, I understand, is in the Musgrave Ranges. It is necessary, of course, since we are observing the southern hemisphere, not to have the telescope too far to the north. When the technical examination has been made 1 do not know which of these three sites, or indeed whether some alternative site - Kalgoorlie, the Flinders Range and Broken Hill all have been suggested - will finally be decided upon. The process of evaluation is, I understand, not a simple one. But at least we know that we have in Australia excellent sites, although we may not at this moment be entirely certain which is the premier site. Whichever one is selected as the best, I hope that we will go ahead without delay in the approval for erecting on it a large optical instrument. The cost will be of the order of £6,000,000 or £7,000,000. Perhaps the lower figure of the two is the more logical, but that may be a matter of opinion.

The expenditure on this project will be spread over a number of years. If we give the lead in this matter it is quite reasonable to expect other governments, particularly the United Kingdom Government, to share in the expense. This is a world project because we want to keep the whole of the southern skies under continuous observation. It is also a world project because the world centre of radio astronomy is likely to be in Australia and a great case may be made out for having your optical instrument adjacent to, or at any rate reasonably handy to, your main radio instrument. From the world point of view there is something to be gained in this. I put it to the House that whereas Australia could not be expected to bear the whole cost of this world project, it would be reasonable for us to give the lead and to take the initiative. I know that it will be objected that future developments may affect our assessment of this matter. It is probable, for example, that when we get a telescope into space and can observe free from the aberrations caused by the atmosphere we will be thinking of optical astronomy in new terms. This development is a long way off but even if it occurs and even if we use image intensifiers and things of that character, which are now becoming available, there is still a tremendous field for a first-class large-aperture instrument here in Australia to be used parallel with our radio astronomy.

I have no hesitation in supporting the bill and the remarks passed on behalf of the Opposition by the honorable member for Fremantle (Mr. Beazley). I suggest that we in this House might, as individuals, do just a little more. We cannot hope to lead in all scientific fields, or indeed in many, but in those in which we do lead - in those in which Australian scientists are in front of the world - surely we should give our scientists our support and our interest. We should know more about what they are doing. We should keep abreast of their progress. I feel that a group - it should not be as formal as a committee - composed of honorable members from both sides of the House should be formed to keep in touch with scientific leaders. The group would obtain information from them on scientific matters that are of practical importance to us in Australia or of theoretical importance to mankind in general.

It will be asked: What is the use of astronomy? Well, I think there may be two answers to that question. First, astronomy may have a great practical use in that it may lead to discoveries in physics which may affect our daily lives and improve our standards of living. After all, all of man's mathematics seems to have stemmed from his primary interest in astronomy, the first of the sciences. I do not think we can write off the hard practical value of what may come from these somewhat abstruse and distant studies. All this is speculative but what is not speculative is that man's urge for progress at this moment seems to be associated with exploring the nature of space - the nature of the universe in which he is placed. It is the astronomer who will give us the physical answers to our queries. We do not know where his quest will lead, but we do know that insofar as some part of our quest, although not all of it, is a material quest, the astronomer is one of the most important people - one of the leaders in humanity - reaching, as we have always said, for the stars. Perhaps the House might take a moment to consider these things.

Mr. CLYDECAMERON (Hindmarsh) [5.58]. - It is always interesting to listen to the honorable member for Mackellar (Mr. Wentworth). Even when he discusses communism he is interesting, although often quite off the beam. But when you get him away from communism any contribution that he makes is always first class. This afternoon he has shown that he is well versed in astronomy. All honorable members will agree that his contribution to this debate is a credit to him and to the Parliament of which he is a member.
Mr. Curtin.- You do not think he is up in the stars?
Mr. CLYDECAMERON. - No, I do not, but I do know that the Communists have not as yet infiltrated the astronomical activities of the Australian National University.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

Mr. CLYDECAMERON.- Prior to the suspension of the sitting I was praising the contribution made by the honorable member for Mackellar. I wish to move now to the bill itself. There is no doubt that Australia has assumed some leadership in the world of astronomical research. This is due in no small measure to the leadership that Australia has received from Professor Bok and from those who preceded him. All were men who devoted their energies and thoughts to the task before them. I know that every honorable member will recall with a great deal of satisfaction the talks that we have bad from time to time by Professor Bok. Those of us who were fortunate enough to be able to visit the observatory on two or three occasions to see for ourselves the work being done by this branch of the university will be more than pleased with the results that we are receiving for the money being expended.
Mr. Coutts.- I was there and saw it for myself.

Mr. CLYDECAMERON.- I know that the honorable member for Griffith was at the observatory. He has taken a tremendous interest in astronomy. Next to the honorable member for Mackellar, he is perhaps the member of this Parliament best versed in that subject.

We should place on record details of some of the astronomical research that is being carried out by the Australian National University. Our scientists have been studying the structure and astrophysics of the Milky Way, the Magellanic clouds and galaxies, stellar astrophysics, positional astronomy and time service. They have also carried out research on stellar interiors. As every one knows, this particular research has been done by the Department of Mathematics of the School of General Studies. In these fields we certainly have made a mark for ourselves in the world of astronomy. As a nation we have every reason to be proud of the contribution which we have made. We should be proud also of the quality of the Australian astronomers turned out by the Australian National University. It is only proper that one should pay tribute to the head of the department, Professor Bok.

It has been stated authoritatively that Australia is now producing young optical and radio astronomers in considerable numbers and - this is important - of a calibre equivalent to the best-trained men overseas. That is a statement with which I note the honorable member for Mackellar is in agreement. The young radio astronomers have available to them very powerful tools for carrying out their research, but the young optical astronomers will be retained for Australia only if they can look forward to having available for their use a large optical telescope of modern design. We cannot expect to keep them unless we provide them with the tools of trade. Every year countries overseas are beginning to recognize the growing importance of astronomy. As the honorable member for Mackellar pointed out, no one can say at this stage the extent to which a knowledge of astronomy may affect even our daily lives and improve our general living standards. I thought the honorable member stated the position most succinctly, and every honorable member who was not in the chamber to hear his speech should read it in " Hansard " for his own edification.

If it is true, as I believe it is and as my friend the honorable member for Mackellar asserts, that this is a field of scientific study to which Australia and the world must pay greater attention, then it is axiomatic surely that as a nation we must supply these young scientists with their tools of trade. What are their tools of trade? In the first place, we must have a large telescope which is capable of doing the work required of it, so that in addition to research we can complement the work of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization radio" astronomers at Sydney and Parkes. These radio astronomers require urgently the presence within easy reach of an optical telescope with an adequate aperture to check without delay on the optical identification of distant radio sources. I thought the honorable member for Mackellar made that point in a pretty compelling way. He pointed out that it was absolutely useless to have one type of telescope unless it was complemented by another type within easy distance. That is the point he was making and I cannot help but agree entirely with his remarks. Perhaps it would not be amiss for me to indicate the kind of work which is being carried out at Sydney and Parkes by the C.S.I.R.O. The radio physics laboratory at Sydney, with the giant radio telescope at Parkes and the ring-shaped solar interferometer under construction near Narrabri, is only one facet of the work being done by the C.S.I.R.O. At Parkes the organization is carrying on research activities, that is, radio studies of the Milky Way, the Magellanic clouds and galaxies, and solar radio astronomy in radio studies of the planets.
Mr. J.R. Fraser. - You would think any fool would know that.

Mr. CLYDECAMERON.- Curiously enough, some people do not know it, and that is unfortunate. I hope that my speech will elucidate the matter and drive home to every Australian that here we have a field of research in which Australia not only can play a great part for itself as a nation but in which it can also make a tremendous contribution to the world's knowledge of this important branch of science.
Mr. Haylen.- Country Party members will get in on the Milky Way.
Mr. Freeth.- If they do, they will want a subsidy.

Mr.CLYDE CAMERON.- The Minister knows his colleagues much better than we do and I think the point he has made is well taken. There is also a standards laboratory in which can be carried out optical studies of the sun's atmosphere, with the aid of highly refined optical equipment.

I wish now to say something more about the large telescope to which I have already referred briefly. From Australia's latitudinal position - this is a point which I think the honorable member for Mackellar has perhaps not yet properly grasped - one can observe one-third of the sky which is not accessible to view from the northern hemisphere. I wonder whether this House realizes what that means.
Mr. Freeth.-Tell us.

Mr. CLYDECAMERON.- My statement means what it says, of course. From our latitudinal position you can see one-third of the sky which cannot be viewed from the northern hemisphere. Surely that is terribly important. This one-third of the sky contains objects of critical importance, notably, the Magellanic Clouds and the galactic centre, which, of course, is the centre of the galaxies, to which we often refer in astronomy. Observations of these with more powerful equipment than is at present available should contribute decisively to the solving of many of the outstanding problems of modern astronomy. I am glad that honorable members agree with that.
Mr. Cope.- We can see Mars better from here than it can be seen from any other part of the world.
Mr. CLYDECAMERON.- The honorable member has made the point that we can see Mars better from Australia than it can be seen from any other part of the world.
Mr. Haylen.- What about Uranus?

Mr. CLYDECAMERON.- I do not know whether the honorable member is correct in assuming that Uranus can be seen more clearly from Australia, but it is a fact that we can see, from this part of our hemisphere, parts of the celestial regions which cannot be seen from anywhere else in the world. This is especially true in the fields of evolution, galactic structure and extra-galactic astronomy. The Magellanic
Clouds, in particular, provide an opportunity to study the structure and evolution of the galaxy with a completeness which cannot possibly be matched anywhere else in the world.
Mr. Wentworth.- Have the Russians got them?

Mr. CLYDECAMERON.- If they had the honorable member would be against them, so presumably the Russians have not got them, because he is in favour of them. In the radio telescope at Parkes and the new Mills Cross to be built near Hoskinstown, Australia will have the finest radio astronomy installations in the world. Properly to exploit the discoveries being made by these installations, it is essential that they be matched by an equivalent optical facility located on the same continent as they are. The concentration of large telescopes and observers in the northern hemisphere is perhaps too well known to need comment. Of the twelve existing telescopes with apertures greater than 72 inches ten, including the five largest, are in the northern hemisphere. Several organizations - notably Eso and Aura - are known to have active plans for establishing major telescopes in the southern hemisphere and we have to do the same.

Australia at the moment is, politically, a very unstable country. That does not mean that it will always remain that way and I believe we ought to be hopeful of the future and plan as though this is a country which can look forward to a stable political situation. I believe there is a large body of competent young Australian astronomers. I understand that tests conducted over several years have demonstrated the existence in Australia of a number of adequate sites for a major optical telescope and I will now deal with some of the proposed sites.

It is interesting to know that the Australian National University, through Professor Bok and the people working with him, has already made a survey of the sites that might be considered most suitable. The honorable member for Mackellar mentioned three of them. He spoke of Siding Spring Mountain near Coonabarabran in New South Wales, Mount Singleton, near Wubin, in Western Australia, and Mount Woodroffe, in the north-east corner of South Australia.

I do not want to appear parochial in this matter, but I would like to make some comments about South Australia as a possible site for this work and for this installation. Of all the sites mentioned by the honorable member for Mackellar, the South Australian is the one which provides the greatest altitude - 4,700 feet. The Western Australian site has an altitude of 2,300 feet, while that at Siding Spring Mountain is only 3,820 feet. Not that that is an important factor or one which could ultimately decide the location of the site. But when one takes into account the fact that South Australia - particularly in the Mount Woodroffe and Flinders Range areas - is the part of Australia which probably provides more clear and cloudless nights than any other part of the continent, I think that condition, in the end, must bring the authorities down on the side of South Australia as a possible site.

I will say no more on the matter. I think I have made it perfectly clear that there is an unanswerable case for Australia to take an even greater interest in this important field of science than has been taken in the past. I believe I have made out an unanswerable case for the purchase and construction of a bigger telescope here. In conclusion, I repeat that I believe that this country is singularly fortunate to have a man of Professor Bok's outstanding ability. He has a tremendous ability, not only to understand his subject but also to convey an understanding of it to other people who are less knowledgeable than he is. If it is not out of place during a debate of this kind I would like to express the hope that Professor Bok will, some time during this sessional period, give us the opportunity to hear him lecture on the possibilities that astronomy offers to this country.

Mr. FAILES(Lawson) [8.19].- Mr. Speaker, I am sure the House is grateful to the honorable member for Fremantle (Mr. Beazley) and the honorable member for Mackellar (Mr. Wentworth) for their scholarly speeches. Their treatment of this subject came from a knowledge of pure science which those of us who do not possess it must surely admire. I do not speak with any knowledge of pure science at all. Unlike the honorable member for Hindmarsh (Mr. Clyde Cameron), I make no claim to a knowledge of pure science. I make the claim that I speak for the man in the street who has an appreciation of the grand work being done by our Australian scientists. I speak as a man who has an appreciation of the applied sciences. There are few of us who do not realize the great value of the work done by the Mount Stromlo Observatory. There are many of us who have had some connexion with radio, particularly during the war years, who will recollect the Stromlo predictions of suitable frequencies to use from time to time and how accurate were those predictions for months ahead. The work of the observatory at Mount Stromlo is very well known to the people of Australia.

The bill, which proposes to extend the making of astronomical and meteorological observations to any part of the Commonwealth, as distinct from within the Australian Capital Territory, has come about because, as the Prime Minister (Sir Robert Menzies) stated in his second-reading speach, there is a need for a field station at some point away from the Mount Stromlo Observatory where clearer viewing is available. I have a definite interest in this bill because the Prime Minister said this -

After the most careful site-testing programme, extending over some years and bringing into consideration at various times ten different sites, it has been decided to establish a field station on Siding Spring Mountain, near Coonabarabran, New South Wales.

I am proud to say that Coonabarabran, in the electorate of Lawson, is my home town. The final selection of this site was made after the most rigorous tests had been carried out at the instance of the Director of Mount Stromlo and the Vice-Chancellor of the Australian National University. I should like to quote from a presidential address given by Professor Bok, the Director of Mount Stromlo Observatory in Sydney on 21st August, 1962. He said -

Mount Stromlo Observatory's biggest handicap over the past few years has been the excessive cloudiness for the site. The establishment of a Mount Stromlo Observatory Field Station on Siding Spring Mountain near Coonabarabran in N.S.W. offers the Stromlo group a first-class astronomical site, and, with the arrival there before the middle of 1963 of the modern and highly efficient 40-inch reflector, our Observatory should be able to step up considerably its productivity.

May I very briefly remind honorable members that Mount Stromlo Observatory for many years operated as an autonomous organization. Some few years ago it became a department of the Australian National University. That is why the university is named in the bill for the extension of the operations of the Mount Stromlo Observatory.

This site, which was decided upon after considerable testing, spread over a number of years, is on a spur of the Great Dividing Range about eighteen miles from Coonabarabran, on the central western slopes of New South Wales. The site is called Mount Woorut, but has become popularly known as Siding Spring Mountain. The Warrumbungle Mountains are very old and were first noted by the Australian explorer Oxley on a journey from the west to the coast. He called them the Black Mountains and found out later that the aboriginal name was Warrumbungle. As time goes on, this site will become very famous. Not only will this field station be built there, but these mountains are also the site of a national park. Visits to the mountains have been made by such eminent men as Captain Frank Hurley, who spent many weeks there taking photographs of what he considered to be some of the most unique mountains in Australia. The Australian Broadcasting Commission has also selected these mountains as a site for a regional transmitter, which will be installed when the fourth stage of television is reached. Tests carried out for the selection of this site showed, amongst other things, considerable freedom from cloud and haze, thus giving astronomers an opportunity of better " seeing ". In other words, the definition from this particular site is much better than from other possible sites.

The site having been chosen, it remained to carry out certain installation work. On 11th May, 1962, the Vice-Chancellor of the Australian National University announced the selection of the site for the field station. This, as he said in the announcement, climaxed four years of comparative tests for cloudiness and astronomical " seeing " from about a dozen sites, narrowed down later to four sites, from which the selection was made.
During the past eleven months a good road has been constructed to the top of

Siding Spring Mountain. For some years an old road led up into the mountain and was used for picnics and excursions. Later the shire council attempted to construct a road over the mountains into the adjoining shire. Then, with the selection of the site, the Coonabarabran Shire Council devoted its attention to building a good all-weather road which, although not entirely bitumen now, will later become all-bitumen to give permanent access in all weathers to the site where the telescope will be constructed. Water is available at the site, electric power has been provided and a radio telephone link is almost completed. The buildings to be constructed will house the 40-in. reflector which is being constructed especially for this particular job. There will be some offices and laboratories, and in July of this year the buildings and dome are expected to be completed. The first major telescope which will be erected on the site will be the 40-in. reflector, which is of modern design and is now being constructed at the Boiler and Chivens Company in Pasadena, California. The instrument will probably be delivered to the site in July or August of this year. The total cost of the telescope, its dome and its buildings, will be approximately £145,000.

This is the first move to establish a permanent field station away from Mount Stromlo. For some years there has been a field station of an experimental nature on Mount Bingar in the Riverina electorate. That site has been superseded as a result of the tests which ended in the selection of the Siding Spring Mountain site. Present plans call for the installation later on the new site not only of this entirely new imported telescope but also of three other telescopes. There will be a 16-in. reflector which, also, is being constructed by the firm of Boiler and Chivens. a modified 26-in. reflector, which is now in operation at the Mount Bingar field station, and the modified 50-in. reflector from Mount Stromlo, which was formerly the Great Melbourne reflector. The Mount Bingar station will cease operation after the transfer of its 26-in. telescope to Siding Spring Mountain. That is a general idea of the developments expected to take place at the new site.

The reason why I am so interested in these developments and why I regard this bill as so important is that this represents the first step towards establishing a field station as an adjunct to the Mount Stromlo observatory, and possibly towards the establishment of a national observatory in this country, perhaps in co-operation with the United Kingdom or Canada. That is something that has been discussed very adequately by the honorable member for Mackellar and the honorable member for Fremantle, and I do not wish to attempt to add anything to the very fine addresses that both those gentlemen gave us. I would say only that, the radio telescope having been established at Parkes by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, we should not forget how important it is to have a large viewing system of optical telescopes to work in conjunction with the radio system. That matter has been discussed very fully by the honorable member for Mackellar. It is of great importance, and we should not lose sight of it.

We should not take the view that we can afford to wait for some time before we consider the establishment of a national observatory at some other site that may be considered suitable. The radio telescope and a large optical telescope should be close enough to each other to collaborate. I do not want to make claims for any particular site. On the basis of my experience and what I have already seen, I believe that the Siding Spring Mountain site now chosen will be the best site in Australia for a full-scale observatory. I do not think that parochial ideas will interfere in any way with the judgment of the people who will be responsible for choosing a site for any national observatory that may be established.

We have in Australia many young astronomers - eager lads who are developing their knowledge and giving of their best in pursuit of the science of astronomy. There must be some means of keeping them here and giving them opportunities to develop the science that they have chosen. This can be done by expanding the facilities for both radio and optical astronomy that we already have. I believe that if we properly support the approach that has been suggested by men so eminent as the Astronomer Royal we shall afford our young men who are seeking to become astronomers the opportunities to which they are justly entitled.

We have to bear in mind another point. Being situated in one of the choice positions on the globe for the purposes of astronomy, we have wonderful opportunities to observe parts of the heavens which are not so readily seen from the northern atmosphere. We have a unique position in this respect and, internationally, we should make use of the opportunities afforded by the geographical position that fortune has granted to us.
Honorable members may wonder why a member of the Australian Country Party is so interested in a science of this sort.
Honorable Members. - Hear, hear!

Mr. FABLES.- I am very pleased to hear the general response which indicates understanding of the interest taken in astronomy by a member of the Country Party. Professor Bok has told me that the response by country people to his lectures has been magnificent. He has been interested to note that country people who he thought possibly did not have much interest in astronomy were particlarly interested in his lectures. I do not want to make odious comparisons between country and city attitudes, but this only goes to show that people who may not have been expected to be interested in those sciences which are a little out of the ordinary run have a very definite and very strong interest in astronomy. Their lives in the open make them familiar with the heavens and stimulate their interest in space and the reasons for the existence of the stars and other sights that we see in the sky on clear nights. So country people are particularly interested in the establishment of any scientific undertaking in a country district, and particularly in the establishment of any station associated with a science such as astronomy.

I say with great pride that the local council and the townspeople of Coonabarabran have been unstinting in their efforts to assist the Australian National University and Professor Bok, the director of the Mount Stromlo Observatory, who has been to Coonabarabran on so many occasions to guide the work that is going on at Siding Spring Mountain. The local people have been unstinting in their efforts to help in the establishment of the field station, for the benefit not only of the Australian people but also of international scientific development. I believe that, once the new field station has been established and is performing the functions for which it is intended, there will be even more pressure for the establishment of a national - or, rather, international - observatory in co-operation with perhaps the United Kingdom or Canada. I am sure, therefore, that this House will support the bill with the very best of intentions for the future of astronomy in Australia.

Mr. ENGLAND(Calare) [8.37].- Mr. Speaker, the reason for the introduction of this bill has already been explained by the Prime Minister (Sir Robert Menzies) in his second-reading speech and by subsequent speakers. This measure is designed to remove any restrictions, in the geographical sense, on the activities of the Australian National University in the field of astronomy. I, like many Australians, have a personal interest in this science. The electorate of Calare, which I represent, has a keen interest in astronomy. That interest has been stimulated by the establishment and working of the radio telescope at Parkes.

I have made only very minor studies in this field of science, but I have always been much impressed by the great spirit of co-operation that seems to the average layman to exist between astronomers from many different nations. On the international plane, co-operation between astronomers is very close. This is excellent not only for the advancement of pure science but also for the general public, who benefit in many ways from such co-operative efforts. This co-operation is excellent for human relations. Perhaps we in this House this evening can, in a very small way, emulate that spirit. If we can, all will benefit. There is no opposition to this bill and I fully support everything that was said by the honorable member for Fremantle (Mr. Beazley), who led for the Opposition in this debate.

It is intended that the head-quarters of flu Department of Astronomy of the Australian National University shall remain at Mount Stromlo. For reasons which have already been advanced, as part of a long range major plan to overcome restricted viewing conditions, a field station i: to be established at Siding Spring Mountain, near Coonabarabran. 1 think that at this stage it is well to look back at developments in the past and to consider the plans that have now been made for the future. This will enable us to get a better perspective and to understand why this bill is necessary.

I think it is safe to say that this phase of scientific study has really captured the imagination of the Australian people. This has been borne out in many directions. First, there is the heavy visiting schedule at the Mount Stromlo Observatory. Then there are the substantial demands made on the director of that observatory and his staff, who deliver lectures to, and generally instruct, people from all parts of Australia. These heavy demands are also indicative of the excellent public relations that are maintained at the Mount Stromlo Observatory.

There is another indication of the way in which the public imagination has been captured in recent times by these developments. I refer to the great number of visitors who have inspected the radio telescope that has been installed at Parkes, in my own area. It is a little over a year since that telescope was put into operation, and already about 15,000 people have been taken on conducted tours of the installation. It seems that people are realizing the value that is flowing from these scientific studies. They know that they have already benefited in one way - from improved weather forecasts which we are obtaining as a result of astronomical observations, meteorological observations and space research in general. People appreciate the results in this field that have been obtained by the use of the weather satellites, particularly in the Tiros and Nimbus series, which are recording cloud cover all over the globe. We are getting practical results from the money spent along these lines. We have also been told that the Telstar series of satellites will contribute much to the improvement of long-distance communications, particularly by means of radio and television. It is interesting to note that only last night Sir Winston Churchill was able to sit in England and watch his son stand in for him when he was granted honorary citizenship of the
United States of America. I am told that this was made possible by the use of one of these satellites.

Let me now refer to the optical side. It has been already stated that Australia has made great contributions to the wealth of knowledge that has been accumulated over the years. As has been pointed out, part of the reason for this is that Australia is favorably situated geographically, and I do not want to labour that point. Much of our success has been achieved with the 74-in. telescope at the Mount Stromlo Observatory. It was pointed out by the honorable member for Hindmarsh (Mr. Clyde Cameron) that of the twelve telescopes in the world with apertures of 72 inches or more, ten are in the northern hemisphere and only two in the southern hemisphere.

It is in the field of radio astronomy that we have made our greatest progress. Australia, of course, is a recognized world leader in this field. This is not simply a brash claim that we ourselves make; it is a statement that has been volunteered by men like Professor Gold of Cornell University and by the Russian, Professor Ambartsumian, who presided at the astronomical symposium in Canberra recently, as well as by the Astronomer Royal himself. These are some of the men who regard Australia as being in the top flight in the field of radio astronomy. We have achieved this position in only about seventeen years, since radio astronomy observations were first made at Dover Heights in 1946. Since that time we have seen the development of a large array of instruments and we have seen the expenditure of a good deal of money. We now have the radio spectroscope at Dapto, we have the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization's radio astronomy field station at St. Mary's, we have the university interferometer at Narrabri, which is already in operation. We have seen an amount of £240,000 set aside for the building of a C.S.I.R.O. radio heliograph also at Narrabri. I am mentioning these installations for a particular reason, which I will give in a moment. The last and most important of all is the radio telescope at Parkes.

Looking at the international picture, it is interesting to see where the money came from for some of these installations. In the case of the Parkes radio telescope, some came from the Carnegie Corporation, some from the Rockefeller Foundation, some from private subscribers in Australia; and I am proud to be a supporter of the Commonwealth Government which played its part in supporting this project by giving more than half of the funds necessary for its completion.

The work done by scientists at Parkes has enabled great advances to be made in the field of radio astronomy. I may say that the results obtained by the main instrument at Parkes have exceeded all expectations. Much of the information that has come from it was completely unexpected. The penetration into space achieved by the instrument has been two to three times as great as that which it was planned for. It has really met with world acclaim.

As we all know, the International Astronomy Union held a symposium in Canberra in March of this year. I think it was the twentieth held by that organization, and it was the first in Australia. It was attended by overseas scientists of very high calibre, men of the very first rank. It is indeed a great compliment to Australia that they should have met here in Canberra. I like to recall the words of the Astronomer Royal, Sir Richard Woolley, who said that Australia has made contributions to astronomy quite out of proportion to its size as a nation.

Plans for the future have already been mentioned. I have spoken of the C.S.I.R.O.'s radio heliograph which is to be installed at Narrabri. Then there is the Mills Cross installation which will be at Hoskinstown. I understand that work is proceeding on this, and that the instrument will be in operation in about two years. Then there is the Australian national radio astronomy observatory at Parkes. It has not been mentioned in this debate that at this site a further telescope has recently been completed. This is a radio telescope with a diameter of 60 feet, mounted on a track a mile long, which is designed to work in conjunction with the main instrument.

On the optical side it has long been a fond dream of astronomers - and I think it has now got beyond that stage - to have an astronomical observatory put into orbit, with a telescope having about a 50-in. aperture and equipped, also, of course, with the necessary telemetric and television equipment to broadcast back to earth what is discovered by that observatory. Of course, the advantage of it will be that it will operate from outside the earth's atmospheric envelope which has a disruptive refractory effect.

You have been told about the important project for the establishment of the European Southern Observatory, which is becoming commonly known as Eso. I think it is as well to mention the countries involved in this project, to show how they combine internationally on these jobs. The nations concerned are France, West Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium and Sweden. They are combining to provide a 140-inch telescope somewhere in South Africa or South America. The United States National Science Foundation has already selected a site in Chile and is ready to go. This is where we see a race developing. The American project involves the provision initially of an 80-inch telescope, with a later one to be installed with an aperture of about 150 inches.

Coming closer to home, as previous speakers have pointed out, it is considered that a large optical telescope is absolutely essential in this country. I do not think it can be too highly emphasized that the two activities should run together. This telescope is to be used for the optical identification of radio sources. At the present moment, the work of the instrument at Parkes is impeded because of the time needed to send information collected there to other parts of the world for verification and to receive information from other parts of the world. This point cannot be emphasized too strongly. Other honorable members have already spoken of the work in this field.

I understand the search for a site has been narrowed to some extent, but many factors must be considered in selecting a site. I do not wish to go into this phase at the moment, and I am not competent to do so. I know the search for a site has extended over the whole of the southern half of Australia. The proximity of this major telescope to other installations is important, and this is where I strike the only discordant note to-night. 1 know that the view of the honorable member for Hindmarsh is different from mine, but I point out that at present we have an interferometer at Narrabri, a radio heliograph being installed at Narrabri, a new field station going in at Siding Spring Mountain and a new 60-feet radio telescope just installed at Parkes and working in conjunction with the giant telescope already there. In this situation, there must be a strong pull towards a site in this area in the central west of New South Wales. I should say that the site should preferably be at a point near the major installation, which is the radio telescope at Parkes, so that there could be quick and direct contact between the radio telescope and the major optical telescope.

I am pleased to observe the decentralization that is following the installation of these astronomical instruments. Perhaps the scientists realize that in the inland areas dust squalls and smoke from bush fires are intermittent and temporary. They probably realize that the smoke, soot, fog, smoke and grime in the atmosphere around a city are permanent. I expect that great work will come from the Australian National University in the future. I hope that our universities will produce many doctors of philosophy in astronomy, who will stay in Australia to work on the instruments that are being provided. The Government should encourage them to stay so that we can stop the export of our best brains. I support the bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

As we go through the tariff proposals, the item to which the debate should be addressed will be readily seen from the right-hand column of the circulated document. 1 appreciate that, in the past, we have had a number of general debates on tariff policy when these various items have been discussed. Mr. POLLARD(Lalor) [8.59].- I appreciate that the Minister for Supply (Mr. Fairhall) in his introductory speech to-night has given details of some improvements that have been made in the setting out of the proposals for consideration by the Parliament. In the past, it has been somewhat difficult to follow the procedure and the method of dealing with the various proposals. All the proposals before us have now been set out with more clarity. This is a very desirable improvement.

We have for our immediate consideration Customs Tariff Amendment (No. 54). This is the result of an inquiry by the Tariff Board into the coffee industry. I do not want to speak at length on the Tariff Board's report, because honorable members will recall that last week the Minister for Trade (Mr. McEwen) made a statement to the Parliament relating to coffee from Papua and New Guinea. In the remarks that I made on that statement I referred to the Tariff Board's report. I content myself with saying that I regret that in this proposal all of the recommendations of the Tariff Board have not been accepted by the Government. The excuse is advanced - maybe with justification - that all of the recommendations of the Tariff Board cannot be put into effect until Australia has completed negotiations with certain overseas countries in accordance with the provisions of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
The Minister for Supply, in his explanatory statement on 15th November, 1962, said -

In accordance with the Tariff Board's recommendations increased protective duties are being imposed on soluble coffee, roasted coffee and liquid extracts. The board has also recommended continued free entry of raw coffee from Papua-New Guinea with increased duties from other sources, subject to a remission of such duties, in whole or part, when specified quantities are obtained from the Territory.

When I look at the Tariff Board's report and the details of the proposal before the committee, I see that the specified quantity was 25 per cent. In other words, if an importer imported 25 per cent, of his coffee requirements from Papua and New Guinea he would receive a remission on the duties imposed on the whole of his imports. I understand that that is the idea. The Minister, in his explanatory statement, also said -

Before the board's findings on raw coffee may be implemented it will be necessary for Australia to negotiate with certain overseas countries. In the meantime it is proposed to maintain the existing tariff duties-
That is, without the recommended increase -

. . and to continue the present arrangement whereby an importer is permitted to import a certain proportion of his needs free of duty under customs by-law provided he purchases a given quantity from Papua-New Guinea.
It is regrettable that we cannot go the whole hog and give the requisite amount of tariff protection in respect of coffee imported from Papua and New Guinea.

The coffee trade is an important one. In terms of world trade, it is even larger than the world export wheat trade. It amounts to about £1,000,000,000 per annum. Australia is increasing fairly rapidly its consumption of coffee. The annual consumption at present is about 17,000,000 lb. The Tariff Board estimates that in five years* time the consumption will be 29,000,000 lb. I am becoming a coffee addict - not because I am particularly fond of coffee but because it has a flavour. Coffee is gaining ground and popularity because of the great influx of coffee-drinking people from Europe. They have been used to drinking coffee. Not all of them come from Sweden where the coffee consumption is 18 lb. per head per annum - Australians consume about 9 lb. per head per annum - but they come from substantial coffee-importing countries.

One of the reasons why people in Australia are being converted to drinking coffee, in my opinion, is that many of the tea importers are importing a lot of rubbish. I do not think there is any doubt about that. If those importers want to keep their businesses going, it might not be a bad idea for them to give the public better quality tea than we are getting at present. That is only my personal opinion. I hope that it is not as wholly correct as I think it is.

My final comment on this matter is that I notice that the Tariff Board has suggested a review of the coffee situation in two years* time. I suggest that the Government consider favorably making a review of the coffee situation in twelve months' time, if it wants to protect more satisfactorily the people of Papua and New Guinea.

I wish to leave the question of coffee for a moment in order to touch on the tariff situation generally. When this Parliament is confronted with sixteen tariff proposals to be debated at one hit, accompanied by 28 or 29 Tariff Board reports - I have not counted them, but the situation is set out fairly completely in them by the board's officers - it should be realized that the Parliament is not giving tariff problems the attention that they should be given. However, that highlights a fact which has been very evident for some time now, namely, that it is the wish of this Parliament - and I believe that we are expressing the wish of the Australian people - that as time goes on this country shall be made more and more impregnable against inroads by imported products that Australians can manufacture.

By doing that we will cater for the increasing population who to-day cannot be accommodated on the land as primary producers to the extent that previous population increases were accommodated. There was a time when there was sufficient good land to induce the rising generations of Australians to become farmers. People had access to land that was made available by the various State governments under closer settlement and soldier settlement schemes. They had an opportunity to become producers of primary products for which there was a huge world demand. I know, Mr. Chairman, that I am roaming slightly from the matter before the Chair, but this is all wrapped up with the question of tariff protection. The present position is worthy of note and passing comment.

Finally, in this slight departure from the matter before the Chair, may 1 say that I am not unaware that, although this Parliament is making Australia impregnable, to some extent, against inroads by imported products and is protecting Australian industries, there is a grave danger that advantage will be taken of this protection and that the Australian people will be exploited behind that tariff wall. That highlights the need for a hastening of the proposed restrictive trade practices legislation. I hope that that legislation will be passed by this Parliament in a satisfactory form. It also stresses the need for some control and supervision of prices charged in this country. I support this proposal.

Mr. DALY(Grayndler) [9.9].- Like the honorable member for Lalor (Mr. Pollard), I am pleased to see an improvement in the method of presenting tariff proposals, but I still think the method leaves a lot to be desired if tariff proposals, which are so important in this day and age and which require meticulous study, are to be considered properly. I hope that further improvements will be made. Perhaps a different method will be adopted and we will not be called upon, as the honorable member for Lalor said, to debate sixteen proposals and 29 or 30 Tariff Board reports, as we are doing to-night. I think you will agree, Mr. Chairman, that unless one is a wizard on these matters it is practically impossible to debate them in detail, as they should be debated. The particular point that I wish to make about the report on coffee is that I am concerned at the delays in the presentation of Tariff Board reports. I am concerned at the effect those delays may have on the industries concerned. The board's report on coffee states that the matter was referred to the Tariff Board by the Minister for Trade on 15th June, 1961. The board finished its deliberations on 27th April, 1962 - ten and a half months later. That is a long time in anybody's book. The board's report was presented to the Minister on 4th May. So almost a year elapsed between referring the matter to the board and the presentation of the board's report to the Minister. But not until seven months later, on 15th November, 1962, was the report presented to this Parliament. So seventeen months elapsed from the time the Tariff Board was asked to inquire into this matter until the report was presented to this Parliament. Now, on 10th April, 1963, about 22 months after the matter was first placed in the hands of the Tariff Board and about five months after the report was first presented to the Parliament, we are given an opportunity to debate it. In anybody's book that is slow work. Heaven help an industry that is having difficulty in carrying on in the face of competition when delays of this kind occur, particularly an industry in which many thousands of persons are engaged, as is the case in the textile industry! I do not say that these delays occur all the time. I know that the Government is aware that delays occur and that it has set up the Special Advisory Authority in an attempt to overcome some of the delays. But the instance I have given to-night is a classic example, and I do not think that it is an isolated case, as I will show later. I hope that some effort will be made by the Government to speed up the presentation of Tariff Board reports. After a report has been delivered to the Minister why should this Parliament be forced to wait seven months before the report is presented to the Parliament? Why should there be a further delay of five months before Opposition members receive an opportunity to debate these reports? There is something wrong with the procedure governing the presentation of these reports, and the matter requires urgent and immediate attention by the Minister. At this stage I do not propose to deal with the pros and cons of the report, but I hope that the matters to which
I have adverted will be considered by the Government.

Mr. TURNBULL(Mallee) [9.13].- I desire to say a few words about the complaint made by the honorable member for Grayndler (Mr. Daly). It must be remembered that the Government set up the Special Advisory Authority to deal with industries that need protection urgently. It is well known that the shortest time in which we can expect a result from a Tariff Board inquiry is about twelve months, but an industry may obtain temporary protection from the Special Advisory Authority within 30 days. Having obtained that temporary protection the matter goes before the Tariff Board for inquiry. If, having completed its inquiry, the board decides that the industry should receive protection, the temporary protection is merged with the permanent tariff protection. On the other hand, if the board at the conclusion of its inquiry is of the opinion that the industry is not justified in receiving protection, the temporary protection obtained from the Special Advisory Authority ceases.

The system of reference to the Special Advisory Authority set up by this Government has been of great importance to industry and has helped to overcome in a large measure the delays referred to by the honorable member for Grayndler. The honorable member correctly stated that there are delays associated with Tariff Board inquiries but pending a finding by the board an industry may obtain protection from the Special Advisory Authority.

The honorable member for Lalor (Mr. Pollard) submitted that the people of Australia wanted more and more tariff protection. He also stated quite truthfully that under protective tariffs unjustifiably high prices may be charged, which would defeat the purpose of protection. I have heard honorable members opposite say that if they had their way they would grant protection against any goods coming into Australia. No nation can hope always to sell and never to buy. This is tedious repetition, I know, but I must say it again in order to get the message across: We must sell goods overseas in order to create overseas credits with which to buy the raw materials so necessary for the functioning of secondary industry in this country. 1 know that we must be fair but no nation can hope always to sell and never to buy. Only when the Opposition realizes this will it cease to make statements like those we have heard to-night from the honorable member for Lalor.

Mr. POLLARD(Lalor) [9.20].- I wish to refer to Customs Tariff Proposals No. 55. When the Minister introduced these proposals he informed us that they covered tariff changes arising from the Government's consideration of the Tariff Board's report on glass fibres and glass fibre products and that, in accordance with the board's recommendations, protective duties of 20 per cent. British preferential tariff and 30 per cent, most-favoured-nation tariff were imposed on fibre glass rovings, chopped strand, chopped strand mat and yarns. Obviously, our international commitments would prevent the raising of duties above a certain level, even if this were required. That is understandable. One must bear in mind that in a negotiation of this kind, although it may appear that we are losing the right to impose a tariff that we may think desirable, we have bargained away that right to obtain a tariff concession from other countries. There is a counterbalance.

The Minister also told us in October of last year that he anticipated that during the then current session of the Parliament there would be a re-draft of the tariff on textile fabrics which should be of material assistance to the Tariff Board in its examination of the general textile reference, and to representatives of industry and commerce who were preparing to present evidence to the board in a series of hearings on this subject. The quite extensive drafting changes involved are incorporated in Customs Tariff Proposals No. 55. These include also an adjustment of the British preferential margin on certain narrow fabrics to implement more fully a recommendation by the Tariff Board.

Not only are we required to consent to the proposed tariff rates on glass fibre and associated products but we must remember also that when the consent is given we shall approve the very many associated drafting changes. No doubt the drafting changes are made to facilitate an intelligent interpretation of the tariff rates on these products. They number well over 100. I think we are justified in assuming that there is no departure in any way from the real intention of the tariff which is imposed upon certain products mentioned under various items in the re-drafted list.

This is a very new industry in Australia and probably very few people know much about it. Fibre glass is used in a much wider range of secondary production than most people would think. The organizations most vitally interested are companies such as Bradford Cotton Mills Limited and several other firms which are mentioned in the Tariff Board's report. The proposed protective tariff of 20 per cent. British preferential and 30 per cent, most favoured nation is not too bad. I understand that tariff was recommended by the board, and I have had no representation from any manufacturer expressing any discontent with this proposal. Besides Bradford Cotton Mills Limited, I understand that the Cyclone Company of Australia Limited is also very interested in this proposal.
Mr. Chipp.- A very fine company.

Mr. POLLARD.-I understand that it is a very fine company and that it was a pioneer in the manufacture of wire products and other industrial items. The Universal and Tygan organizations have come to Australia, I understand, to undertake production of the items under consideration. I leave the matter at that.
