Mr. KELLY(Wakefield) [9.26].- Contrary to what happened on the last occasion on which tariff proposals were before the committee, I propose on this occasion to speak only on five of them. I think that this will be a relief to honorable members on both sides. Certainly it will be a relief to me. I have already told the Minister and the department what I intend to say on these proposals and therefore some authoritative replies should be forthcoming to the questions which I shall raise, which, to my mind, are of some significance.

As the honorable member for Lalor (Mr. Pollard) has mentioned, Customs Tariff Proposals No. 55 deal in part with the Tariff Board's report on glass fibre products. The major portion deals with the dull but necessary business of bringing our customs schedule into line with overseas procedure. This is known technically as adopting the nomenclature. When the Minister foreshadowed the introduction of these proposals, in October of last year, he made it clear that no changes of substance were intended. He said that this would be only a machinery measure. I was particularly disturbed to find that this is more than a mere machinery measure. I shall cite one of many instances. Items 105 (a) and 105 (d) (1) (a) (1) refer to fabrics that are principally used for drapes or upholstery. The new item 460 (c) (4) refers only to furnishing fabrics. That did not mean much to me when I saw it first, but I have since learned something about it. Under the old proposal the materials from which bridal gowns are made carried a duty of 2s. 8id. a square yard. Under this so-called machinery measure the new duty will be 7s. 6d. a square yard, because the department now can say that the material comes within the scope of furnishing fabric and so attracts the higher rate of duty. Under the umbrella of this machinery measure the duty was increased from 2s. 8id. to 7s. 6d. a square yard. The Minister when he fore shadowed this, said no such thing was intended. He said that such a proposal would not involve any changes in duty and would be essentially a drafting measure. It is a question, not of whether the duty should be higher or lower, but of whether the duties should be effectively altered without being submitted to this chamber. These were duties recommended by the Tariff Board and passed by the Parliament and they have now been altered under the umbrella of a machinery duty which we were told was only a machinery measure.

It is not easy for us to follow these tariff schedules. It may be easy for you, Mr. Chairman, but not for lesser mortals like me. It is terribly difficult for me, at least, to follow the implications of these schedules. If we cannot have confidence in the statements of the Minister and the actions of the department in things like this I find the position very disturbing. I think I would be totally unjustified in imputing wrong motives to the department or the Minister and I believe this alteration has happened by accident. Probably no deception was intended; I do not know. All I know for certain is that it happened and I would like an assurance from the Minister this will not happen again.

Mr. Daly.- Mr. Chairman, I ask for guidance. At what stage in the debate on these measures - if any - may I make, broadly, a second-reading speech in regard to the position of imports and exports because of the Government's tariff policy and matters of that nature?
The CHAIRMAN.- At no stage at all during this debate.

Mr. FAIRHALL(Paterson - Minister for Supply) [9.32]. - One of the problems about the question raised by the honorable member for Wakefield (Mr. Kelly) is that for many years there has been difficulty in establishing definitions of what constitutes a furnishing fabric. It must be clearly understood that many of the fabrics we are dealing with to-day can be used for purposes other than furnishing. If one goes over the history of definitions in this matter one sees the difficulties which have faced and are constantly facing the department, and which extend also to the rag trade, if I may use that term, in establishing what is in fact a furnishing fabric.

Back in 1951, when protection was first given to furnishing fabrics, the definition was "piece goods of the type used for furnishing and upholstery, woven or jacquard or dobby type looms". That is to say, it gets down to damask types of material. In 1956 the definition was changed and became " piece goods, woven, weighing 6 ounces or more per square yard, of the types which, either as imported or when further processed, are ordinarily used for furnishings, drapes, upholstery, &c".

In October, 1960, the wording was changed to cover materials principally used as furnishing fabrics. Unfortunately, over the years, the use of the terms " ordinarily " and " principally " have served merely to cause confusion regarding the type of material and have placed on the department the extraordinarily difficult task of administering the intent of the Parliament in fixing these duties.

In 1959 the Tariff Board, as the result of an inquiry, cleaned up this matter by producing a common rule - by removing the differentiation between furnishing fabrics and non-furnishing fabrics. In other words, we had a common tariff and for a while there was no problem in differentiating between furnishing fabrics and non-furnishing fabrics, because they were at the same rate of duty. In December, 1960, as the result of a further change and the introduction of temporary duties, this confusion crept back into the definition of furnishing fabrics and non-furnishing fabrics. During 1962, I understand, the department treated the old item - fabrics to be used as furnishing fabrics - as meaning simply furnishing fabrics. It is true that a certain amount of discretion had to be used in establishing whether a fabric was a furnishing fabric of whether it was one which patently was to be used for other than furnishing purposes.

The fact is that up until now the trade has never been able to produce a proper definition by which this matter might finally be resolved and put away. But there is at the moment a new reference before the Tariff Board, which will be asked to produce a clarification of the position, either similar to that which existed in 1959, during which there was a common tariff, or in some other way to establish finally which is a furnishing fabric and which is not. Until that matter has been finally established by a further reference to the Tariff Board, which will be aided and abetted by the best advice from the industry backed, plus or minus, by the determination, I am afraid the honorable member for Wakefield must be patient and assist the department to find a definition in this matter which will make the administration of the Tariff Board and tariff recommendations workable. Mr. CLAY(St. George) [9.35].- Mr. Chairman, it is useless to ask the honorable member for Wakefield (Mr. Kelly) to produce a definition of what constitutes a furnishing fabric and what constitutes a dress material. Mr. POLLARD(Lalor) [9.48].- These are indeed most important proposals, dealing with one of the most essential industries ever established in Australia. I have only the Minister's press statement. I do not have the statement he made when he introduced the proposals to this Parliament. The duties that are to be imposed are of a protective character. There are also drafting changes, as in previous cases. There are increases of existing tariff rates. For instance, the existing duties on drilling machines are 27i per cent. British preferential tariff and 35 per cent, most favoured nation tariff. The proposed duties are 27i per cent. British preferential tariff, as before, and 40 per cent, most favoured nation tariff - an increase of 5 per cent, on the existing duty.

If one looks at the history of the metalworking machines industry in Australia, one finds that an enormous amount of progress has been made, particularly since World War I. I do not know of any more important engineering activity than the manufacture of machine tools, which include lathes, milling machines, drilling machines, sawing machines, bending machines and every type of machine that the mind of man has conceived for the working of metals efficiently and satisfactorily. In Australia there are many competent firms producing machines of the highest grade - equal, or almost equal, to machines obtainable anywhere else in the world. That is not to say that some substantial improvement could not be made by some Australian manufacturers of machine tools.

I suggest that if one searches the world for excellence in machine tools, one would find the highest degree of excellence in Switzerland. The Swiss are masters of the production of precision machinery. No doubt, this is an outcome of the precision that they have always displayed in the manufacture of watches and so on. If one wanted to go further, one could then turn to Sweden. The Swedes, by virtue of their great skills, their application, the availability of very high grade iron ore and their capacity to produce metals of the highest quality, manufacture machine tools of very high grade indeed. This does not mean that we in Australia are not now making some machine tools equally as good as those made in the countries that I have mentioned, and that we shall not be able, if accorded tariff protection, to improve our products and manufacture a wider range of machine tools than is now the case.

The difficulty that has always confronted the machine-tool industry is that, when we go beyond drilling, milling and sawing machines, lathes and the like, we find ourselves in a highly-specialized branch of engineering and machine-tool manufacture. The market for milling and gear-cutting machines is relatively small compared with that for drilling machines and simple sawing machines. Although the progress made in the engineering industry in this country owing to the necessities of war has enabled us to manufacture these kinds of machines to a degree of excellence equal to that attained in other countries, I think that I ought to say again, as I have always said, that there is need for Australians to display greater thoroughness in the manufacture of many of their engineering products. It is true that one can buy more cheaply a machine that is rough and not well finished. But, after all, not so much extra cost is incurred in making a good job of the machine.

If this country is to extend its export trade, particularly to South-East Asia and the Asian continent generally, machine tool products offer scope for increased trade. It is well known that we in Australia can do all sorts of things in the field of precision industrial equipment. I recall seeing displayed in King's Hall during war time an artillery range-finder manufactured in Australia by the Department of Munitions with the co-operation of some of the big private-enterprise engineering firms. If we can manufacture range-finders, the production of which requires the exercise of great engineering skill and precision and a high degree of know-how concerning the use and production of machine tools, as well as an extensive knowledge of mathematics, astronomy and goodness knows what, we can manufacture almost anything in this country.
The Opposition offers no objection to the relatively mild increase in protection which is to be accorded to the machine-tool industry under these proposals. Indeed, we are happy to facilitate them.

Mr. POLLARD(Lalor) [9.54].- Mr. Chairman, Customs Tariff Amendment (No. 60) relates to fabrics used in the manufacture of belting other than impregnated, coated or laminated transmission, conveyor or elevator belts or belting. I think that this amendment will probably interest the honorable member for Wakefield (Mr. Kelly). It deals with fabrics that are woven into belting of a special size, form, shape and weight for conveying power from all sorts of motors and prime-movers to all kinds of industrial machinery on the farm, in the factory or anywhere else. This amendment is the outcome of a temporary duty recommended by Sir Frank Meere, the Special Advisory Authority, at the rate of 20 per cent, ad valorem on belting fabric, wholly, partly or chiefly of cotton or man-made fibre and weighing not more than 18 oz. a square yard. No doubt this belting is in some instances cut into strips much narrow than 18 inches wide - perhaps 2 inches wide, or the width of belting that I would normally describe as balata belting - and cemented or glued to make an excellent product.

I have seen no reference so far to the Tariff Board report, but I suppose that this amendment is backed by such a report and that the report states that, in the main, these fabrics are made of cotton or manmade of this fabric is told whether the whether the customer who buys belting made of this fabric is told whether the fabric is made of man-made fibre or principally of cotton. Furthermore, I should like to know the relative merits of the two types.

It appears that the Tariff Board proposes duty at a flat rate of 20 per cent, on belting made of either man-made fibre or cotton. I am not sure whether the Minister can enlighten me on this, but I imagine that he can. I am inclined to think that belting manufactured from man-made fabric would be stronger than belting made of cotton fabric. I think that if one fabric used in the manufacture of belting is better than another, we ought to be told that that is so, and some preference should be accorded to the better fabric when a tariff is fixed. After all, belting is one of the most important items used in the industrial life of the community. That is well known to everybody who has a motor car. If the fan belt breaks, the owner of a motor car is in real trouble. A fan belt made of cotton material may not last as long as one made of man-made fibres. I should like to have the Minister's advice on these matters.

Mr. KELLY(Wakefield) [9.58].- Mr. Chairman, I wish to discuss specifically the proposal for increased duty on rubber belting fabric. You may recall that when the measure authorizing the appointment of special advisory authorities was being considered in this place last year, I pointed out as vehemently as I could the danger of the system that is now operating - the danger of applications for increased duty being shuttled backwards and forwards between the Tariff Board and a special advisory authority. My gloomiest forebodings have been proved justified by events. This shuttling backwards and forwards has happened all too frequently. I shall mention this again and again during the consideration of these Tariff Proposals.

Because I like to economize in the use of words, I have been searching for a descriptive phrase that would adequately describe this process that I have just mentioned. Several come quickly to mind. One could describe the present arrangements as a yo-yo system under which duties go up and down like a yo-yo, or as a backwardsandforwards system or even a stop-and-go system. I cannot claim any credit for originating the use of the phrase " stop and go ", however. The expression that seems to me to describe most succinctly the process by which references are passed backwards and forwards between the Tariff Board and a special advisory authority is the term " shuttle system ". That expression has the virtue of being simple and descriptive. For the rest of this discussion I shall use the term " shuttle system " to describe this process, the danger of which I have already pointed out.

Coming back to this duty on belting fabrics, it is interesting to go over the timetable that forms the background to this duty. The temporary duty of 20 per cent. was imposed as a result of a report of the Special Advisory Authority on the reinforcing material of which the belting is made. The previous duties were imposed in May of 1961 - not very long ago. According to the Special Advisory Authority the old duties seemed to average about 50 per cent., which one would think would be a pretty reasonable rate of protection for an economic and efficient industry. This new impost increases the duty to about 70 per cent. You could leave the case there with slightly raised eyebrows and say that this is a pretty heavy protection. But if you are going to examine the matter in detail you cannot leave it at that, because this is only the beginning of the story.

This fabric is used to make rubber belting, and rubber belting has been the subject of two Tariff Board inquiries since May, 1962, when the Special Advisory Authority granted emergency protection of 5s. per square foot in addition to the old 17i per cent. rate. As a consequence of the report of the full Tariff Board, which followed, it was decided that the emergency protection was not high enough, and the rate was increased to 27i per cent., with the temporary impost removed.

With this rough time-table in mind let us look in detail at the Special Advisory Authority's report on the fabric, justifying the new duty. Sir Frank Meere, the Special Advisory Authority, admits in his report that the imports are not coming in in great quantity, but the manufacturers of the fabric fear that they may come in in the future unless the duties are increased. This evidently has not happened yet, according to Sir Frank Meere's summingup of the situation, but it may happen in the future. Well, I am a farmer. I may have a drought next year, but no one worries about me, I am just one of those who help to produce our export income. Why should any one be concerned about me? But when the manufacturers feel that imports may come in, although Sir Frank Meere says they are not coming in now, something must be done about it.

But I must not be bitter about this. Let us return to the matter of this particular duty. Evidently the manufacturers of the fabric feel that they should not be asked to reduce their prices, although the Tariff
Board, after examining this subject, had this to say: -

It is apparent- and I quote from the Tariff Board's report, which preceded this by only a few months - from comparisons which the board has made, that, in respect to conveyor belting, the price by Australian manufacturers to local weavers of the cotton reinforcing fabric, which represents approximately SO per cent, of the total factory cost, is significantly in excess of the duty paid price of imported fabric.

Evidently the manufacturers of these fabrics felt that they had to have the opportunity to price considerably above duty paid prices. The Tariff Board felt that if they could get their fabric at a reasonable price the manufacturers of belting could produce the belting cheaply. That is what the Tariff Board said. The Special Advisory Authority felt that imports might come in even over the existing 50 per cent, tariff wall, and because he felt that the manufacturers should not be asked to reduce their prices he imposed the extra 20 per cent.

But this will not solve the problem. Sir Frank Meere admits this, with his typical candour, to which I have often paid tribute. The manufacturers of the belting will not be able to buy cheap fabrics from overseas because of this duty, so they say it would be much better for them to import the belting direct from their associated overseas companies. In this connexion I again quote Sir Frank Meere, when he was talking about this very duty that he intended to impose -
This, of course, would mean that, irrespective of what protection is given, the Australian manufacturers of belting fabric would lose the whole of their market.
This is the duty that he recommends which he says will lose the Australian manufacturer the whole of the market. Then he goes on -
This inquiry, however, does not relate to belting, and my consideration must be limited to the belting fabric only.

So there it is. Sir Frank Meere has imposed this duty, which he admits will be effective only if imported belting is prevented from coming in, and the only way to do this is to increase the duty on belting, which was imposed only on 4th October last year as a result of the Tariff Board's report. I point out to the committee that I prepared these remarks in written form. Tariff Board reports and Special Advisory Authority reports come at me in bewildering profusion, and I have got into the habit of dealing with them as they come. I wrote this in January, when I said, " This probably means that there will have to be another emergency inquiry on belting, and this will have to be followed by a full Tariff Board report on belting". This is exactly what happened. Later on in these proposals you will find another report on the belting that is made from the fabric. As I said, I considered that another emergency inquiry would be necessary, and the report of the Special Advisory Authority following that inquiry came to hand a few days ago. I am not going to speak at great length on the effect of the increase of the duty on fabric, but I am going to devote myself later to the inevitable increase which Sir Frank Meere foreshadowed must come. He said that there must be, to make this duty effective, an increased duty on the belting in the manufacture of which the fabric is used.

I am going to leave the matter there and wait until the belting proposal comes up for discussion. I simply use this as an illustration of the danger inherent in this system, with the Tariff Board divorced, as I pointed out it would be, from the other fiscal arm. Neither of those arms seems to be quite sure of what the other is doing.

Mr. CLAY(St. George) [10.7].- It might be thought by some persons listening to this debate that the manufacturers of this kind of fabric are starting at shadows when they talk about their fears of possible importations of fabric manufactured overseas, and suggest that they require an increase of the duty of 50 per cent. This increase they received, of course, the duty being raised to 70 per cent. Others might think that the Australian manufacturers were hopelessly incompetent, and that as a result of their incompetency and that of their employees, the skilled workmen in this industry, it was necessary to secure protection. The fact of the matter is that Australia accounts for only about 1 per cent. of the world production of this material. It is produced in other countries in far greater quantity than we produce it in Australia. Because of this great quantity of production in other countries there are occasions when there is a surplus of the commodity. Certain importers always seek to take advantage of these surpluses, because the fabric is then available at reduced prices.

I also think that our manufacturers have friends overseas who can apprise them of possible developments which might be harmful to Australian manufacturers. As a result of information secured in that way, from friends overseas, they have made an approach to the Special Advisory Authority, and, as a consequence, we now have before us an increased protective duty.

I do not think that our manufacturers start at shadows. They have pretty good advance information of what is likely to be brought here from overseas, and they took the step of protecting themselves before the damage was done. I congratulate them on having done so. Far too frequently we find in this country that the damage is done before any protection can be obtained.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Mr. DONCAMERON (Lilley) [10.12]. - As most honorable members know, a Freedom From Hunger Campaign is being conducted throughout Australia at present. I can think of no more opportune time than this to direct the attention of the Government to the hunger that exists amongst the pensioners of Australia. Since I was elected to this House some sixteen months ago, I have repeatedly heard honorable members on the Government side boast of the great development, growth and prosperity that has occurred in Australia since the Government took office. The usual practice is to measure the prosperity of a country by the living standards and conditions enjoyed by the people. Honorable members opposite claim that our people to-day are enjoying better living conditions than they enjoyed a decade ago. Yet information I have received and investigations I have conducted show that, in the midst of all this growth and development and all this so-called high standard of living, 745,094 age, invalid and widow pensioners and their dependent children are living in the shadows of death from starvation. This is brought about by the lack of growth and development in tie rate of pensions paid by the Government.

I have here an extract from a " Vitamin Research News Letter " compiled by Science of Life Books Proprietary Limited in association with Vitamin Supplies Proprietary Limited, 51-55 Warrah-street, East Chatswood, Sydney, which states in part -
Vitamins Sustain Life!
The following appeared in the Sydney "Daily Mirror" of 6/6/62:- "Five out of six of Sydney's pensioners keep alive with vitamin pills" a Macquarie Street specialist said to-day.

The specialist said pensioners would starve without the pills because they could not afford a proper, balanced diet. . . . " lt is costing the Federal Government a fortune for vitamin pills which are free to pensioners," be said to-day. " But all general practitioners in Glebe, Marrickville and other less-privileged areas of Sydney know that many of their pensioner patients would soon die of vitamin deficiency if they did not get help."

We have never advocated the use of vitamins in lieu of food. It is deplorable that in Australia, known around the world as a food-producing nation, there should be so many pensioners lacking a balanced diet, and that doctors must prescribe vitamins to maintain the spark of life in these elderly people.

Not once have I heard honorable members on the Government side of the chamber raise their voices in defence of the pensioners Not once have they protested to the Treasurer (Mr. Harold Holt) or to the Minister for Social Services (Mr. Roberton), calling for an increase in pensions to help these people to ward off starvation and death. On the contrary, a senior Minister said that if he had an extra £40,000,000 to spend, he would put social service benefits last. In effect, he would sentence the pensioners to death by starvation.

Unless emergency measures are taken to introduce legislation that will increase the pension rates by at least £1 a week, many pensioners who are weakened by an insufficient food intake will die during this coming winter, and the responsibility for this will rest on the Government. An increase of £1 a week in the present pension rates would cost less than £50,000,000 a year. That is not a large sum of money from a gross national product that exceeds £1,000,000,000. It is not a large sum of money when it is remembered that it is being spent to preserve life. An extra £1 a week in the hands of our pensioners would permit them to purchase the extra food they need so badly. This would be £50,000,000 a year placed in immediate circulation. It would create a demand for our home grown and manufactured foods and in turn would give the economy a much-needed shot in the arm. It would set in operation a chain of events that would benefit the country in many ways.

Sir, wehave a Christian, moral and social obligation to provide for the care and wellbeing of the people who are too old, too sick or, through other circumstances, are unable to care for themselves. I appeal to the Government to introduce emergency legislation before the next Budget to provide an increase of at least £1 a week in the present pension rates.

Mr. FOX(Henty) [10.18].- I was most distressed to hear the honorable member for Lilley (Mr. Don Cameron) speak as he did. He said that he has never heard honorable members on this side of the House speak in support of pensioners. I remind him that during the term of office of this Government the rate of age pension for a single person has increased from £2 2s. 6d. to £5 5s. a week and for a married couple from £4 5s. to £10 10s. This is a higher percentage of the basic wage than was ever given to pensioners. This Government introduced a pensioner medical service; the Labour Government gave the pensioners nothing. This Government introduced a supplementary rent allowance of 10s. a week for those pensioners who live alone and who pay rent. Labour did not give any such allowance. This Government has continually eased the means test so that pensioner couples to-day may have an income from superannuation or from other sources of £7 a week and still draw a pension of £10 10s. a week. They have a total income of £17 10s. Compare them with the men who are on the basic wage. They are receiving only £14 8s. a week and they are trying to feed, clothe and educate their children. This Government has increased the limit of the means test to £9,500. When this Government came into office, if a couple had £1,500 in addition to owning the home in which they lived and their other personal belongings, they received no pension whatsoever. This Government raised that limit from £1,500 to £9,500. That made more people eligible for the pension. It is completely wrong to say that honorable members on this side of the chamber have never spoken up for the pensioners.

I have received representations asking me whether I would support a pension equal to half of the basic wage. I do not mind telling the House what I have told members of pensioners' associations and councils which have asked me about this matter. I am quite prepared to support a pension in excess of half of the basic wage for one pensioner only; but I will never support the payment of a pension equal to half the basic wage to each of two pensioners in the one family. I do not think that any working man who thinks about that proposition will support it, irrespective of whether the basic wage is £14 8s., as it is to-day, or £40 8s. Virtually no pensioner couples have dependants. The honorable member for Lilley spoke about 745,000 pensioners and their dependants. The age pension is payable to women 60 years of age and over, and to men 65 years of age and over. I cannot see such people having very many dependants. If you suggest that these people, towards the end of their lifetimes, when many of them have paid off their homes and have no rent to pay, should be in a better position than the man on the basic wage, I do not think you will get many workers to support that proposition,
Mr. Einfeld.- How much do you think the age pension ought to be?

Mr.FOX. - I cannot hear the interjection. I assure honorable members opposite that the pensioners have more friends on this side of the chamber than they have on the Opposition side. We have shown that in a practical way. 1 would support a better deal for the single pensioner who is finding it hard to exist on the pension that is given to him at present; but I do not subscribe to the proposition put forward by the honorable member for Lilley, namely, that hundreds of thousands of pensioners are existing on vitamin pills. That is sheer hysterical nonsense. That statement is not true. I know nothing about conditions in Queensland; but, in addition to what the Commonwealth Government does for pensioners, I remind him that many of the councils in my State of Victoria, including two of the councils in my electorate, help pensioners with meals which are delivered to their homes, lt is absolutely ridiculous and hysterical nonsense for the honorable member to speak as he did to-night, however well-meaning he may be. He should present the true picture to the people; that is, that this Government stands for the best possible deal for pensioners.

Mr. DUTHIE(Wilmot) [10.23].- Mr. Speaker, I wish to speak on a different subject from that mentioned by my friend, the honorable member for Lilley (Mr. Don Cameron) and the honorable member for Henty (Mr. Fox). It is partly related to the subject of pensioners, which was mentioned by both of those speakers. I refer to the poor quality tea that is coming into Australia at the present time. I have in this saucer a sample of the tea being sold to people in Australia to-day. It is a sample from my State of Tasmania. It was bought in an ordinary grocer's shop in an ordinary half-pound packet. As far as I know, Mr. Speaker, the origin of this stuff is Ceylon.

This sample is powdery. It is almost like dust. When the tea is poured into the cup, this stuff floats on the top. Dust clouds arise when you pour it from the packet into a container, lt smells more like chaff than tea. Really, you would not recognize it as tea if I could give it to you, Mr. Speaker, and let you smell it. All through it are white sticks of tea leaf that were not filtered out of it before it was packaged. Those are just a few of the faults of this stuff that is being sold in Australia to-day at a pretty high price, although this is one of the cheaper types of tea.

This sort of tea is not fit for human consumption. Yet thousands of our pensioners who are forced, by economic circumstances, to buy the cheaper brands are drinking or trying to drink this substance that is called tea and which comes into Australia under the cheaper brand names.

I am wondering whether the tea that comes into Australia is inspected at the point of entry. I do not know who would do that. Perhaps it would be done by health inspectorsor customs officials. Unless there is a tightening up at the point of entry we will be deluged with this cheap, bad-looking and bad-smelling tea for a long time to come. It is up to this Government, through the Department of Trade which handles these matters, to ensure that the quality of tea imports is standardized. In other words, we should have a standard of quality that is applicable to all brands of imported tea. Obviously, we have no standards at present because this type of tea would not get into Australia if we had adequate standards. I have no complaints at all about some of the better known brands, but it is wrong that this stuff should be allowed into Australia. I ask the Department of Trade to have a good look at the imports of tea and to tighten up the inspection, if there is any inspection, in order to prevent the admission to Australia of the sort of stuff that I have shown to the House to-night.
Mr. Einfeld.- That tea is like the Government. It is very weak.
